reviewText:
DNF was one of the most anticipated games of all time...Slaughtered by over-hyping.
Is DNF a bad game ? No. No it is not.
Is it what we all wanted to be ? No. No it is not.

Gearbox lied about many things. They promised us a campaign that is 12-16h long...I managed to beat the game in 9-10h in the HARDEST difficulty setting.
So let's start this off by listing some of the biggest cons:
-The old Duke is hardly back". The one-liners are all good but there's few of them...Just put on repeat.
-The levels are all rather linear not "sandboxy". It's basically a corridor shooter.
-Regenerating health. What were they thinking?!?! That old-school Duke fans from the 90's really want that ? Yea...Logic!
-2 gun limit. Later patched-raised the limit to 4.

Basically no ammo
recommended:
health pickups to look for because of the regening hp. Ammo is thrown at you in boss fights so no need to be careful with ammunition anyways...I guess this also explains the linear level design.
It all comes down to this: Lazy work! I blame Gearbox for being lazy and doing just a quick moneygrab on a known and over-hyped franchise/character!
The game is simplified. You don't really need to think or be extra careful like in the original Duke Nukem 3D.

The game's still fun tho. Most people who say it's the worse game ever or the worse game of 2011...Those people are full of shait!
The game itself runs very well. I didn't encounter any glitches

reviewText:
I wanted to like Duke Nukem Forever. I really did.

When early reviews criticized the game for poor graphics, crude/outdated humour, dumb AI, and linear levels, I gave the game the benefit of the doubt and hoped that the bad reviews stemmed from unrealistic expectations - expectations that were inflated to reflect the 10+ years that the game was supposedly in development for.

Having spent many, many hours with DNF, I regret to say that the game is indeed a disappointment. It isn't all bad. Aside from inexplicably playing too much like a Halo/COD clone for my liking, I find the game's biggest issue to be the technical problems that have put me in a position to constantly replay the beginning of vehicle-based levels because something about those levels significantly ramps up the extent to which the game locks up/freezes on my computer.

Here is an analysis of the major factors that comprise this game:

PLOT: There is a plot, but it's pretty weak and uninspired. If anything, it gets in the way of the action that this game revolves around since there are instances where you're foreced to wait for NPCs who are blocking your path to stop talking until you can proceed to your next objective. Listening to these NPCs should be optional!

GRAPHICS: For the most part, they look fine for what they are. Duke Forever never aspired to be the graphical successor to Crysis, so it's silly to compare it to such graphically astounding titles. Although the enemies look cool and much more menacing than they did in Duke Nukem 3D, some of the backgrounds seem very bland (i.e. Duke's Hotel) or feature details that stand out as very, very pixelated (i.e. Sunshine reflecting off of the wall of a large barn in the 'Ghost Town' map). The game looks a little too dark and gritty for my liking.

SOUND: The reworked theme song notwithstanding, the game's music is nothing to write home about. The sound effects, on the other hand, are very well done. Jon St. John's voice acting for Duke is superb; it lends the game personality and makes me laugh because it is just as buffoonishly over the top and anachronistic as it was when Duke first started speaking in 1996.

Critics who whine about how dated Duke Nukem comes across in DNF need to get their heads checked. Telling anonymous women to Shake it

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever. 15 years in the making and yet here I am, considering if it couldn't have used a couple of more years in development. The truth is though, 5-10-15-20 years it wouldn't have mattered. The problem here isn't lack of development, it's the direction of the development.

All the fluff is there though. Playing this game you will never doubt that this is a Duke game. Scantily clad women are everywhere and you will rarely walk more than ten feet between the various pop culture references, jokes and other nonsense. If anything Gearbox deserves some credit for getting that part of the franchise right. The humor is there, the silliness, the crazy. What they got wrong, is the mechanics.

Playing Duke Nukem Forever is like playing every FPS made in the last 10 years. Gearbox certainly did. They added every cheesy feature the genre has ever experimented with. You got your vehicle sections, your turret sections, your button mashing quick-time events and so on and so forth. Any sense of the fast paced, old school style of FPS that made Duke Nukem 3D the icon it is today is long gone. Instead we have a Duke that's become old and arthritic. This Duke isn't the badass Duke of old. This Duke leans on stamina bars, regenerating health, limited weapon slots, scripted events and linear maps.

Instead of the sprawling maps of Duke 3D, that had you running, jumping, flying and swimming all over the place, looking for secrets and keycards you play through entirely linear and fully scripted sequences and fights you do not allow you to progress until you've killed what the game wants you to kill and listened to whatever irrelevant dialog the game wants you to listen to. The entire experience is slow and dull and there is little to look forward to besides the naked ladies and the occasional proper joke.

Duke Nukem 3D was a masterpiece of adolescent insanity, of old school fast paced shooting, of innovative map design. Duke Nukem Forever has captured the adolescent part but lost everything else in the shuffle. What's left is a mediocre shooter with a bunch of nudes thrown around.

Duke Nukem Forever is not a very good game. It's a game that doesn't stay true to it's old school roots doesn't even compare to the original. Even by modern standards it brings nothing new to the table, just a bunch of rehashed concepts and ideas. Nothing is new, nothing is better than what's been already done.

All in all. For those that have been waiting, hoping for a good old school style shooter, this ain't it. And for those that just want a decent modern shooter to pass the time, this ain't it either. They might get the crude humor right but everything else, just ain't Duke.

reviewText:
Like a hyper-violent, over-sexed Peter Pan, Duke Nukem refuses to grow up. Though 12 years have passed since the events of Duke Nukem 3D, he's the exact same trash-talking, cigar-chomping, muscle-bound man of action, still rocking that '90s-style buzz cut and red tanktop. The source of his superhuman action-hero powers is his own ego, which doubles as a literal recharging shield over his (also recharging) health. It's reinforced by an entire world of people who worship him as an infallible man-god and sex idol—women want him, men want to be him. He's the stereotypical teenage boy's power fantasy personified and turned up to 11. Sure, he's a ham-fisted action hero parody, but Duke remains one of the most memorable characters in gaming history for a reason: he's simply more fun to play as than SERIOUS FACE ARMY MAN.

As two-dimensional as Duke himself, the story gets right to the point: intergalactic sex-criminal aliens are re-offending, and Duke must defy orders and step in to defend Earth's chicks. Even that flimsy B-movie tribute plot is resolved (sort of) half way through—DNF becomes simply about shooting aliens 'cause they're ugly, and bits of the script are little more than profane Mad Libs. Lazy writing or pointed critique of the state of story in first-person shooters? I prefer to think of it as the latter.

Action-wise, the single-player game fulfills its obligations as a successor to Duke Nukem 3D. It's fast-paced run-and-gun battle against diverse, love-to-hate 'em monsters, using weaponry ranging from conventional boomsticks toover-the-top sci-fi, and fought through a long series of corridor levels where there's almost always something unique to see and interact with. Almost every original weapon (except Duke's boot) returns—and after taking the Shrink Ray and Freeze Beam for a spin, it makes me wonder why few shooters have appropriated the joy of killing enemies in two-step attacks. Sure, shrinking enemies and then squashing them or freezing and shattering isn't as efficient as double-tapping to the head, but it's more fun. There's also the Devastator, a ridiculously powerful, double-barreled, rapid-fire rocket launcher that never pauses to reload until it's spent.

Duke's trusty pistol, shotgun, Ripper chaingun, and rocket launcher may not be anything particularly unique or special (and certainly not realistic, lacking even a hint of recoil) but they're loud and potent alien killers. The new weapons, a rail gun sniper rifle, an alien laser, and a triple-missile-launcher called the Enforcer Gun are pretty ho-hum—no new classics here. The biggest sadness is that DNF has adopted the Halo-style two-weapon system, which frequently forced me to abandon my beloved Shrink Ray for lack of ammo. Even with all of that heavy weaponry, I still died quite a bit—despite the regenerating health system, Duke Nukem Forever is one of the more challen­ging shooters I've played in years.

At least the signature remote-detonating pipe bombs, laser tripwire mines, and Holo-Duke decoys (plus melee-enhancing steroids and pain-mitigating beer powerups) exist outside this limitation, allowing you to set all manner of devious traps in the diverse range of linear, corridor-style levels and lure enemies into them. Duke battles the aliens through his high-tech Duke Cave, his self-styled opulent casino, the aliens' disgustingly organic hive (complete with Prey-style sphincter doors that open when tickled), a Vegas skyscraper, a Dukeburger restaurant, Hoover Dam, construction sites, Nevada canyons, underwater, and more.

The old-style design is probably due to the fact that DNF should've come out years ago. (Hell, 2K's recommended PC is built from five-year-old hardware.) Here and there, it shows; while alien monsters look pretty cool—particularly the iconic Pig Cops and flying, tentacled Octabrains—humans and many of the environments look well behind the curve. But thanks to the aliens' comical massacre of EDF (Earth Defense Force) troops, you don't spend a lot of time looking at people, so it only really offends when the incompetent President waves his unarticulated fingers in your face.

Pop culture references are similarly out-of-date—even growing moldy. Considering that the freshest ones I caught date back all the way to 2004's Team America: World Police (excluding reenactment of Christian Bale's 2009 meltdown in the opening and a crack at Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare tacked on at the end), most of Duke's one-liners were probably recorded in the early half of last decade. Though Duke still delivers several chuckles per level by quoting '90s films like Pulp Fiction and Starship Troopers and jabbing at Halo, it's noticeable that he's been living under a rock for quite some time.

The most innovative puzzle gimmick is shrinking Duke down to a few inches tall and sending you scurrying through levels made for man-sized play. Being action-figure sized gives you a new and interesting perspective on the world—jumping around a vast kitchen battling rats and mini Pig Cops among the shelves while using mustard jars as cover is a very different experience, and one encounter in particular makes an epic battle of what would normally be a one-shot kill. However, running any significant distance on tiny legs can get tedious.

Action is also varied up with frequent turret-shooting scenes, most of which are thankfully short and punchy, and two separate driving sequences: one as mini-Duke in an RC car, one in an oversized monster truck. Both are longer than they probably should be, as the uncharacteristic lack of guns on Duke's cars limits you to repeatedly running over enemies and turbo-boosting over jump after jump.

One category in which DNF has surpassed its predecessor by leaps and bounds is in its uncensored nudity, particularly in the first half. Breasts abound, some attached to shapely but dead-eyed ladies, some to other, less appealing things. If that kind of thing bothers you, you've probably already been warned away by the long-as-your-arm ESRB rap sheet—but my personal taste threshold was exceeded only once, by a mid-game incident that goes just a little too far in mixing boobs, comedy, and gore.

Other points of pain are the checkpoint-only save system, which is at least courteous enough to only rarely respawn me farther from the point of death than I'd have liked, and mercifully brief quick-time events—mostly just tapping Space bar for feats of strength.

DNF is a throwback to the age when shooters were long single-player experiences first and multiplayer games second, and as such the eight-player multiplayer modes aren't going to challenge Call of Duty or Battlefield for the competitive crown. It's often hilariously effective at showing us a good time, though—the 10 maps, which are diversely designed with the same wide range of locations as the campaign, are built to create goofy and memorable moments when combined with Duke's weapons.

It's a healthy chunk of game, too. The Steam clock read “10 hours played” when I'd finished the single-player run on normal difficulty, and that's without devoting time to posting a high score on the pinball machine or conducting a thorough search for secrets. Completing the game unlocks classic, why-doesn't-anyone-do-this-anymore cheats like character head scaling, and I might have to replay at least part of it just to see that absurdity in action.

I'm sure that years of anticipation will spoil Duke Nukem Forever for some—there's no getting around that at the end of that long road is only a good game and not an amazing one. It is what it is. He may not be at the top of his game, but even after all this time, Duke still knows how to party.

Recommended Despite All The Hate It Gets
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
It's normal to have high expectations on a game that's been in development for more than 10 years, but to judge it it's important to know a little of its development history to understand why they took so long to finish it.

It was remade from scratch many times because of the engine or graphics being outdated, they wanted it to be perfect, or at least as groundbreaking as the original Duke Nukem 3D was at its time. Due to this fact, many of the original ideas planned for the game didn't make it to the final product as can be seen in its many trailers.

But then, when all hope was lost (with 3D Realms closing) Gearbox appeared and saved the day buying the Duke Nukem license. And then the game was released. Was it groundbreaking? No. Was it awesome? I wish... Was it bad? No, and that's what it's important.

If you don't know the history of its development, the final product (at least the bulk of it, not counting the makeup and multiplayer Gearbox added later) was finished by 2009, and due to budget and legal problems, the game felt a little old even for that time. So probably most of its ideas were nice and new for 2005 maybe, its not bad! But not as impactating as they wish they were (if they decided to change it, it probably would have never been released).

Plot wise, it isn't something jaw dropping, it is something you would expect from a Duke Nukem game: Duke is loved and desired by the women, men admire him, and kids want to be like him, it's all going well until an alien mothership comes to Earth. The problem is, they're not being hostile... yet. As the story unfolds (doesn't take too long actually) everybody finds out that the aliens plan on abducting the women, and kill everyone else, ESPECIALLY Duke Nukem, so it's up to the King to go rescue the babes and save the world once again.

Graphically, it isn't outstanding by any means, but Gearbox did a really good job poilishing it, the blur and depth of filed effects are really well implemented. You can notice a few low res texture here and there (most noticeable on the console versions) but it shines at times like in the Cycloid Emperor fight at the start of the game or in the Mothership battle a bit alter on. What really is kinda of ugly, it's the animations, the characters move unnaturally and don't have many facial expressions, reminded of Quake 4 NPCs. On the other hand, the enemies are very detailed and in general really well done.

In the Sound department, it lacks a more compelling soundtrack, but the voice acting is really well done, Jon St. John returns as Duke doing a really great job. The other NPCs sound a little ridiculous sometimes, but that's intended. The one-liners return and (fortunately for me and unfortunately for others) the old ones come back too. There aren't many good ones within the introduced in this game, but some really have the spirit of the franchise.

Gameplay was one of the most controversial things about this game, I thought it was too linear run and gun with regenerative health (ego) as most FPS games are nowadays, and that's what disappointed me. Don't get me wrong, it's fun to play, but I expected it to be more open ended like Duke 3D. I was hoping for something that would really differ (in a good way) from all the games we have today. There are puzzles here and there and I enjoyed them, to reduce the pace a little to not get too repetitive. The other games references were funny and not offensive like most people think they were, Duke Nukem 3D featured a dead space marine.." (Duke's voice) and played just like it

reviewText:
First off I'd like to start by telling how much I enjoyed this game. It was entertaining and fun. By it's name ironically yes it did take ''forever'' to make this game, 12 years to be precise.
When it was announced back in 2011 people were really excited. It was all over 'the promise that was made 12 years ago' was finally going to be fulfilled. So people got excited, suddenly people that didn't even know Duke Nukem became a Duke Nukem fan just to be on the 'Hype Train' by knowing the game took 12 years to develope they skyrocketted their expectations, what wasn't known was that The Game Company actually went bankrupt in the process of the making of the game and had to postpone it.
Even in the game you can see in what conditions they developed the game. Sure it took long but at least they were man enough to finish what they started. If you weren't a fan of the game before It's not surprising not to like this.
But for the real fans it had everything. Duke's Egoism, Beer, Women, Nudity, Violence, Fun... So yeah I enjoyed the game very much as much as any other real fan. It's not the best game of all time but It's also not as bad as everyone says.

HAIL TO THE KING BABY!

reviewText: Tens of millions of dollars, over 14 years spent in development, at least two engine switches and four development resets... all for a game that plays nothing like Duke Nukem. The gameplay is mediocre, unsatisfying and generally not fun. There's no exploration in the levels, no secrets and nothing beyond linearity. The weapons handle badly and are limited to a two or four weapon limit, but the levels have all been designed with a two-weapon limit in mind, which means no ammo and the mandatory use of some weapons in certain sections. The game wastes its energy with a poorly written, poorly thought out story that shouldn't even be there. The graphics are horrid and the post-processing (which is the only way to make it look decent) will ruin your eyesight. Seriously. The multiplayer isn't much to write home about, either - it's based on the singleplayer so you have the same terrible weapons, and the level design is generally pretty awful.\n\nThe fact that Gearbox considered this fit for release tells you volumes about what sort of developer they are. And the fact that 3D Realms went from a perfectly great game ready for release in 2007-2008, to spend even more time and money to port this game to consoles, redoing all the levels and mechanics so it'd play best on an Xbox, tells you much about how this game ended up taking over 14 years in development. If you can get it for cheap, give it a try, but keep in mind that this is Duke in name only.

reviewText:
Is it worth the wait? Of course not, don't be ridiculous. How could any game possibly be worth waiting 14 years for, especially one that only ever aspired to be a low-brow comedy first-person shooter? There's no reinvention of the genre here, no real attempt at grandeur. More than anything, Duke just wants to party like it's 1997.

Check unrealistic expectations at the door and forget the ancient, hyperbolic promises of self-deluded developers before you even consider buying this suddenly corporeal ghost of PC gaming history. The development-time-to-awesomeness ratio isn't impressive. If you can do that, Duke Nukem Forever can at least mostly succeed in its aspiration. After all of its tumultuous history, it's ended up as an entertaining FPS wrapped in juvenile, smut-laced humor. Its gameplay is a hybrid of old-school and new, and it won't wow players with stunning visuals—its window of opportunity for that passed years ago—but it does put on a good show of alien ♥♥♥-kicking by working what it's got.

The Cycloid is one of the cooler-looking bosses, but his bark is worse than his bite.
Like a hyper-violent, over-sexed Peter Pan, Duke Nukem refuses to grow up. Though 12 years have passed since the events of Duke Nukem 3D, he's the exact same trash-talking, cigar-chomping, muscle-bound man of action, still rocking that '90s-style buzz cut and red tanktop. The source of his superhuman action-hero powers is his own ego, which doubles as a literal recharging shield over his (also recharging) health. It's reinforced by an entire world of people who worship him as an infallible man-god and sex idol—women want him, men want to be him. He's the stereotypical teenage boy's power fantasy personified and turned up to 11. Sure, he's a ham-fisted action hero parody, but Duke remains one of the most memorable characters in gaming history for a reason: he's simply more fun to play as than SERIOUS FACE ARMY MAN.

As two-dimensional as Duke himself, the story gets right to the point: intergalactic sex-criminal aliens are re-offending, and Duke must defy orders and step in to defend Earth's chicks. Even that flimsy B-movie tribute plot is resolved (sort of) half way through—DNF becomes simply about shooting aliens 'cause they're ugly, and bits of the script are little more than profane Mad Libs. Lazy writing or pointed critique of the state of story in first-person shooters? I prefer to think of it as the latter.

Incoming canned goods!
Reloaded

Action-wise, the single-player game fulfills its obligations as a successor to Duke Nukem 3D. It's fast-paced run-and-gun battle against diverse, love-to-hate 'em monsters, using weaponry ranging from conventional boomsticks toover-the-top sci-fi, and fought through a long series of corridor levels where there's almost always something unique to see and interact with. Almost every original weapon (except Duke's boot) returns—and after taking the Shrink Ray and Freeze Beam for a spin, it makes me wonder why few shooters have appropriated the joy of killing enemies in two-step attacks. Sure, shrinking enemies and then squashing them or freezing and shattering isn't as efficient as double-tapping to the head, but it's more fun. There's also the Devastator, a ridiculously powerful, double-barreled, rapid-fire rocket launcher that never pauses to reload until it's spent.

I just want to be looooooved!
Duke's trusty pistol, shotgun, Ripper chaingun, and rocket launcher may not be anything particularly unique or special (and certainly not realistic, lacking even a hint of recoil) but they're loud and potent alien killers. The new weapons, a rail gun sniper rifle, an alien laser, and a triple-missile-launcher called the Enforcer Gun are pretty ho-hum—no new classics here. The biggest sadness is that DNF has adopted the Halo-style two-weapon system, which frequently forced me to abandon my beloved Shrink Ray for lack of ammo. Even with all of that heavy weaponry, I still died quite a bit—despite the regenerating health system, Duke Nukem Forever is one of the more challen­ging shooters I've played in years.

At least the signature remote-detonating pipe bombs, laser tripwire mines, and Holo-Duke decoys (plus melee-enhancing steroids and pain-mitigating beer powerups) exist outside this limitation, allowing you to set all manner of devious traps in the diverse range of linear, corridor-style levels and lure enemies into them. Duke battles the aliens through his high-tech Duke Cave, his self-styled opulent casino, the aliens' disgustingly organic hive (complete with Prey-style sphincter doors that open when tickled), a Vegas skyscraper, a Dukeburger restaurant, Hoover Dam, construction sites, Nevada canyons, underwater, and more.

This little piggy is coming for blood.
Oh yeah, and there's a shameless strip club level with no combat—it's mostly a showcase for boobs and a playground for the many interactive games (pinball, air hockey, billiards, video poker) and gross-out moments in the bathroom. No two settings are alike, and with plenty of Easter eggs scattered around that boost your health when interacted with, exploring the world is a frequently rewarding high point.

Blast from the past

At the end of these levels lie some old-school-tough boss battles. Almost all of the hulking beasts took me out at least once before I figured out and exploited their attack patterns (notable exception: the final boss). Fights against a mothership, a massive alien queen, an underwater leech, and others are more about the spectacle of fighting huge unique monsters (plus an excuse for Duke to nut-punch something for an ego boost) than creating interesting gameplay.

It's Duke vs. Goliath.
The old-style design is probably due to the fact that DNF should've come out years ago. (Hell, 2K's recommended PC is built from five-year-old hardware.) Here and there, it shows; while alien monsters look pretty cool—particularly the iconic Pig Cops and flying, tentacled Octabrains—humans and many of the environments look well behind the curve. But thanks to the aliens' comical massacre of EDF (Earth Defense Force) troops, you don't spend a lot of time looking at people, so it only really offends when the incompetent President waves his unarticulated fingers in your face.

Pop culture references are similarly out-of-date—even growing moldy. Considering that the freshest ones I caught date back all the way to 2004's Team America: World Police (excluding reenactment of Christian Bale's 2009 meltdown in the opening and a crack at Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare tacked on at the end), most of Duke's one-liners were probably recorded in the early half of last decade. Though Duke still delivers several chuckles per level by quoting '90s films like Pulp Fiction and Starship Troopers and jabbing at Halo, it's noticeable that he's been living under a rock for quite some time.

Eh, it's Vegas. They were probably going to tear that hotel down and build a bigger one anyway.
Meatheaded

I encountered a lot more puzzles (of the jumping, physics, and switch-throwing varieties) than I'd expected, and few are befitting of Duke. Dropping barrels into one end of a shipping container to tilt it and create a ramp is too mundane a task for a super badass—Duke's not making fun of the puzzles other shooters started using a decade ago here, he's imitating them. Poorly.

The more innovative puzzle gimmick is shrinking Duke down to a few inches tall and sending you scurrying through levels made for man-sized play. Being action-figure sized gives you a new and interesting perspective on the world—jumping around a vast kitchen battling rats and mini Pig Cops among the shelves while using mustard jars as cover is a very different experience, and one encounter in particular makes an epic battle of what would normally be a one-shot kill. However, running any significant distance on tiny legs can get tedious.

80/100

reviewText:
Duke Nukem 3D is one of the best games I've ever played. A fast, lightweight, cool-looking, cool-sounding, interactive shooting experience.

Duke Nukem Forever is none of those things. It's slow, heavy, visually dated, lacks any interesting voice clips or music, and has you ducking behind cover every two seconds like some late-2000's ♥♥♥♥♥game for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  If that's what you want, that's okay... except you'd probably be better off playing something else. I bought the Balls of Steel edition on Amazon for like 20 bucks, cuz it came with a Duke bust that I can put on top of my copy of Duke 3D, a superior game. Which you can play co-op, by the way. UNLIKE FOREVER.

Oh well. At least it finally came out. 2/5

reviewText: Expecting an embarrassing trainwreck to laugh at, I was incredibly surprised when Duke Nukem Forever became my favorite FPS since HL2. I am serious. It has satisfying gunplay, a similar gameplay structure of action, driving and puzzle solving, and great atmosphere. It's really solid all around, and somehow struck a chord with me, probably due to its fascinating development history. DNF will always have a place in my gaming heart.\n\nP.s.: The DLC is great too and complements the campaign nicely.

Duke Nukem comes back to a dated engine,dated gameplay and especially dated humor.On a gameplay standpoint,it's anything but refined.Most of the guns lack of oomph and are visually unimpressive.Especially the shotgun's almost compressed blast that sounds always the same.Still, I'd be lying if I said that I didn't enjoy it. Why? Because you fight hordes of space aliens that blows up just right under your assault,and it's good fun to realize that any gun is good, not only rifles or RPG's.This means that you can actually carry your golden pistol the whole game because it's that useful

For a current-gen game,Duke falls short.But for an experience coming straight from the past, it's a blast to play.I wouldn't say it's a must-buy,but definitly a rent. And bring friends along,you'll laugh until the credit rolls

If you were a real Duke fan back in 1996, you will love Duke Nukem Forever.

reviewText: Duke Nukem Forever had a lot of hype surrounding it when it first came out, and the unreasonably high expectations made a lot of gamers feel let down when they actually played the game. The game attempts to reference Duke Nukem's past, and they do an alright job of it. The storyline itself is rather longish, with different puzzles, interactive scenes and boss fights to keep you occupied along the way, The voice acting could have used more work (especially the way they made Duke Nukem generally sound), and even though the storyline is longish it still seems like once you've finished the game it was too short.\n\nThe DLC The Doctor Who Cloned Me" gave the game a bit of a boost along with it's nearly dead but still alive multiplayer community. These two should give you a bit more gaming time. I would recommend getting this game when it's on sale because the normal price to buy it is currently too much in my opinion for what this game offers. Hardcore Duke Nukem fans would probably enjoy this very much
date: but younger gamers or gamers that are not familiar with the Duke Nukem series would not understand the raunchy references this game makes or the style of humor that Duke Nukem has always used.\n\nOverall
recommended: this game on sale + the DLC and multiplayer would be pretty fun for a casual gamer to play. There are also many references to other games that came out around the time that Duke Nukem Forever came out; casual gamers would definitely enjoy that."

reviewText: While its not perfect and without a doubt has its flaws, Duke Nukem Forever diserves more credit than how the public has treated it. Its gameplay is solid and is a good deal longer than what most AAA games would consider. Maybe I'm too soft, but I can say that I had a blast with this game, and if you give it the chance, maybe you will too.\n\nIt may not have been worth the 14 year wait, but its still worth something, and its definately worth your interest if you have any love for games of the past era, or for the King himself.

reviewText:
So, here we are. Duke Nukem Forever. I picked this one up really late because honestly I avoided it a lot, and after all this time, after the dust has settled, lets just see how this game truly is.

First of all, prior to writing this review I decided to investigate a bit in the 15 years it took this game to be developed and the whopping 20-30 milion dollars invested in this (Wikipedia source: While the game neared completion, the funding began to dry up. Having spent more than $20 million of their own money, Broussard and Miller asked Take-Two for $6 million to complete the game. According to Broussard and Miller, Take-Two initially agreed, but then only offered $2.5 million. Take-Two maintained that they offered $2.5 million up front and another $2.5 million on completion. Broussard rejected the counteroffer, and on May 6, 2009, suspended all development.)

Holy ♥♥♥♥. All that money

reviewText: In all of Gaming History, there's only a few titles that hold a place in our MS-DOS Childhood Hearts & Minds, Duke Nukem Forever is one of those titles. What was once supposed to be our MS-DOS King; Duke Nukem's 1996 Sequel to Duke Nukem 3D, it entered an Endless Vaporware Cycle that lasted 1996-2011 which became Apogee Software's biggest downfall. Apogee Software was once a great MS-DOS Company that I miss so much, their once inovation of DOS Classics via BBS became a tragedy in all of Gaming History.\n\nIf this game was released back in 1998, Apogee Software would have continued proudly. But they stalled it for over 10 years which caused them to lose everything. By 2009, it was all over for Apogee Software. And then, Gearbox stepped in to save the day in 2011 by completing and Releasing Duke Nukem Forever. We all thought that Duke Nukem would never see the light of day. So, I agree with Gearbox: Duke Nukem Can't Die". And so
recommended: Duke Nukem is back from my MS-DOS Childhood Days to Next-Generation HD & he is here to stay!\n\nAnyway

You will not be disappointed with the Good-Old Fun Times with Duke Nukem as he blows up the Aliens to Kingdom Come!\n\nHail to the King

reviewText:
After waiting for years after a sequel to the legacy that is Duke Nukem 3D I can only say this about the sequel: It's a ****ing mess. I wish I could love this game, especially after pre-ordering it, but it's a game that has no idea about its own legacy or how to properly offer a good FPS experience.

This game went through so many numerous reboots, engine changes, and change of directions, and it is visible in the final product. Stuff is literally all over the place. Occasionally you'll see a nugget - a glimpse of the greatness it could have been. However, as soon as it shows you that nugget it takes that same nugget, covers it in Propynol and shoves it where the sun don't shine.

If you can get this game for less than 5 dollars it is an interesting historical lesson. If you pay more than that and know how god-awful it is, you are most likely a masochist.

reviewText: Duke Nukem Forever. A game that, somehow, survived perpetual delay limbo. As a game by itself, it's not worth the price of admission. It brings nothing new to the table, serving more as a small tour through popular genres that evolved through the decade of development, from its release. As a Duke Nukem game, maybe. Given the lack of actual games between this and Duke Nukem 3D, besides spin-offs, it's potentially worth for a bit of modern nostalgia. Though, such reasoning is rather fleeting, as its gameplay mechanics contrast the seemingly dated theme to try and seem modern, which drags itself down significantly.\n\nIf you're fond of Duke Nukem enough that you need a fix, go nuts, but pick it up on a sale. For anyone new to the character an story... Super big maybe, but you might find more fun in Duke Nukem 3D instead.

reviewText:
First thing's first, I put this game off for way too long and having just beat it I felt the need to post a review for it.  I had heard the game was terrible and, as I didn't want to ruin the nostalgia that I felt for Duke Nukem, I decided that I was going to avoid this title.  I was so, so wrong to judge this game before experiencing it first hand.

The game may not be perfect, but it is definitely fun.  I found it to be as enjoyable as any first person shooter that has been released in the last few years.  Duke is back in all of his glory and the gunplay is a blast.  His crude one-liners are more than welcome after the decade plus that I've waited for a worthy return and I found myself laughing frequently.

The mechanics of the game run flawlessly.  I didn't experience a single issue the entire time I played and the aiming and character controls are top notch.  Every single death and missed shot in the game felt like it was 100% my fault and not some aspect that was overlooked by the developer.  Another aspect of the game that I enjoyed was that, although the number of weapons to be found is about on par with the other games, all of the remained viable throughout the game.  They all have their pros and cons that you can use to your advantage for each situation that you find yourself in.  It also should be mentioned that, unlike the vast majority of FPS games out there, the game never felt monotonous to me.  One moment you'll be running and gunning, the next you'll be platforming after being shrunk down to the size of a can of soup, and the next you'll be manning a turret as hordes of alien ships and reinforments are en route to kill you.

There are two parts of Duke Nukem Forever that keep it from being an absolute gem, however.  First, is the restriction on the number of guns that you can carry.  Duke Nukem used to be a walking arsenal.  Every weapon that you found in the game you kept for the rest of your campaign and could use it at any time as long as you had the ammunition for it.  The second improvement to the game that could have made it a classic would be the vehicle controls.  Driving Duke's monster truck, while fun to run over aliens with, was a bit more of a hassle than I would have liked.  It wasn't absolutely terrible but it was enough that I was less than excited when I saw it ahead of me and knew that I would be driving instead of running and gunning which I would have preferred.  Fortunately, you don't spend very much time in it.

I recommend this game to any first person shooter fans and especially to old Duke Nukem fans.  I had a blast and played it from start to finish in about ten hours over the course of four days.  This -is- the worthy successor to Duke Nukem that I had hoped it to be and I had to get the word out about my experience!

reviewText: Duke Nukem Forever ist probably best know for its development history: after numerous changes of engines, faked trailers, a long silence and a lawsuite, Gearbox Software (today probably best known for the Borderlands games), finished the game. It was probably not the best for their reputation as the game is average through and through. Die graphics is roughly on the same level as Half-Life 2, without the great systems for animations and facial expressions. It follows the blueprint of a classic first person shooter, which includes puzzles in the levels whch are all well done. The rest ist mostly standard fps level design, only in very few instances the genius level design which made Duke3D a masterpiece shines through. I noticed that quite a lot of arenas are in the game, where the player is trapped and has to defend multiple waves of enemies. The weapons are part standards like a pistol and a shotgun and part crazy weapons like the ice- and shrinkray, but nothing that veterans of Duke3D aren't familar with. But they are not as effective (or should I say: overpowered?) as their counterparts in the predessesor. Since only four weapons can be equipped at the same time (two if the option is deactivated), I decided not go for the exotic weapons but more for the standards to be prepared for most situations. The number of emeny types is quite low, also mostly well known foes. But their behaviour has change quite a bit, making them a new challenge. But some more different ones would have been good. The driving stages are no highlight as especially the buggy with its huge tires is a agile as a rubber boat. The game has though bossfights, which range from very good like the one against the alien queen (which does not only require fast fingers but a bit of thought) to average like the one against the Octaking.\nBut that can be the summary for the whole game: nothing is really bad, but the highlights are far and few, making the whole game quite average. For fans of classic fps games it is worth picking up in a sale.

reviewText:
The game itself overall is pretty poor, completely linear, uninspired gunplay, dull gameplay, its rather mind numbing in parts, I loved Duke 3D it was one of my favourite games back in my childhood but this reboot is far worse than the original, it suffers from the problem modern FPS games do alot, linear scripted experience. Exploration is non existant there is only one path if you deviate away and find some alternative way like see a little hole drop in (like seriously 2ft deep) die, instantly. Huge gripe, TURRET SECTIONS I really dont think anybody enjoys these and this game has alot of them. Has mouse accelerate or something on, the mouse reacts too much and isnt very accurate, playing with the settings helps but it still doesnt fix the over compensation, PC versions of games really should do away with those settings I think they only annoy people like myself.

It does have some redeeming quality's the humor is bang on the mark for Duke, i liked the ego system somewhat but its not quite the same as say having secrets they are always infront of you and you'll find you just click anything you can 'use' to see if it gives you ego, most of the weapons are fairly lame but there are a few like the shrink ray and the triple shot rocket launcher thing.
It has alot of mini games you can take a go of but that doesnt interest me, i came for Duke not to play pinball.
It has alot of variety in levels but in most cases its tedious and annoying, the driving parts are really mind numbing like the casino shrink part it loses its novelty really quick, then your using your pick-up truck to get to various places along the linear path and it just gets really annoying.
Some of the puzzles arent too bad.

Would I recommend it? as a game no, if it didnt have Duke Nukem in the title it would have tanked hard, the selling point here is in the brand name. A bland FPS with honestly not that much shooting in parts, alot of turret sections and completely on rails action from the get-go with a few tedious mini-games.

However if your after a trip down memory lane with Duke and some of his classic humor it may be worth the price tag when its on 75% off, i bought it on 75% off, i didnt feel ripped off i got a few hours out of it but i really did have to force myself to play it out, very mind numbing game.

Overall score 3.5/10

reviewText: The first problem with the game is this: Long dragging out intro and little shooting, for the begining of the game that is. There aren't many new guns that are worth using *three new ones in total i think* and really the only one thats good is like some alien sniper rifle which doesnt really fit Duke's personality.It's very linear and they didn't even bother to hide it, or maybe they did but screwed up. The little mini-Game like things you do to gain more ego are cool at first but get boring after a while do to lack of creativity with them *one of them being....wall boobs?*. The boss battles are pretty anti climatic as you always have infite ammo lying around in an ammo crate and they always supply you with a rocket launcher or an explosive weapon,because thats the only thing you can use against them,except for one where you use a mounted minigun that for some reason Duke Nukem cant tear off.There arent any secrets lying around that will help you, i mean whats the point when ammo is lying around everywhere. The 2 weapon thing is in this game which i hope dies off in FPSs soon. The multiplayer isn't that great either. You all play as Duke on red team or blue team with the only differences are some shirt colors and hats that make you look stupid. The multiplayer is the same as most MMS multiplayer modes with the shrink ray and freeze ray changing up a bit. You have this thing called My Digs which would be really cool if you could move your stuff around or customize your furniture. The dlc is fun though!

reviewText:
So let me just keep this short. This is not the game anyone hoped for or wanted.
The game should have been buried along with 3d realms. Duke Nukem Forever
is not fun, it is not entertaining. The gameplay is actually awful, the combat is
embarrassing. I love Duke Nukem 3d, it is a phenomenal game. It was revolutionary
a triumph for the first person shooter genre. This game ♥♥♥♥♥ on his memory and
no matter how much you love Duke Nukem, you will be hard pressed to try
to enjoy this new entry into a franchise that should have died with fondness
and in the accolades of PC gaming.

Sadly gearbox decided to cash in on the hopes and 12 years? Of hype behind
the fabled “Vaporware” title DNF. It should have been buried along time ago, this
game is not fun, it is not funny. There is nothing here for anyone. The highlight
of my 10 hour playthrough (second to hardest difficulty) which was absolute
torture throughout. Was microwaving a rat, that was about it. In addition to about
3 new quips from John Saint John (voice of Duke) that made me smile, there is
nothing here.

Just buy Duke Nukem 3d Atomic edition, that is what you want. There is even
an HD pack widely available for the game now so it doesn’t look THAT awful.
So buy that instead of this waste of hard drive/virtual space.

Avoid like the black plague.
2/10

reviewText:
Was 12 years of waiting worth it? Let's find out with this late review.

Duke Nukem Forever is not a bad game as everyone says, but it's not good. I see what they wanted to try, I really do, bring back the good 'ol classic shooter game 1999 style. But let's focus on the good things before and then let's point out the problems.

The game itself doesen't even look so bad, the textures are really good, and the graphic it's good looking, and can run smooth even on not-so-great pcs with high settings.
The gameplay it's fun.. for most of the time; there are many weapons, from the classic pistol to the weird alien ones. Not a lot of renovations of gameplay, and not everyone of them are actually good. Why does game desingers think that water level where you can drown are fun to play?
The game it's pretty long, and haves a lot of different locations. The map desing it's pretty good looking, but it's mostly a hallway for most of the game, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it, I never had problem with invisible walls, but here I couldn't reach almost nothing becouse of them. Jeez.

Anyway, can't think of anything else. Let's focus on the problems.
As I said, this game is a straight up line, expecially at the beginning. The enemies aren't so much difficult to kill, and fortunatly the power ups are hard to find.
They added cars, but that didn't help much. Seriously, a monster truck? What am I, 6 years old?
The Humor it's terrible: maybe it's just me, but an alien with 3 boobs on his chests just gross me out. It seriously looks like the humor of Saints Row, stupid, childish and immature, and I hate it. But it had a few funny moments.

I don't wanna waste more time finding all the little problems, but I just wanna point this out: this game doesen't have the main thing: it can't be 100% Duke nukem. For lot of parts I was feeling like playing another game; I don't know if they was references, probably yes, but lot of stuff was like ripped off from Doom 3, Half Life 2, Halo and for god sake, even Call of Duty. Easter eggs or not, that doesen't make the impression of a original game.

Final Score: 5+/10 for effort.
And mostly understanding. 12 years in the making, 3 different games developers's houses.

At least it wasn't so much glitchy. And some boss battles where actually interesting.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever took everything that made Duke Nukem Total Meltdown a success and threw most of it out the window.

Mistake #1: Weapon limits. Duke is the main man and he doesn't deal with weapon limites.

Mistake #2: Ego Health. Completely changes the dynamics of the game. The orignal health and armor was good for
building the tension in the game. Ego bar... run, dodge and hide until you health comes back. (Anyways that
ego bar plus weapon limits makes him feel more like Halo and Duke is too cool for that.)

Mistake #3: Half of Duke's items. No more reusable health packs? No more jet packs?! No more scuba gear?!?
No more protective boots!!!! Half of Duke's cool toys are gone...

These might seem to be minor but add it all up and Duke is missing a cornerstone that made him so cool but they did do some things right in this game too. Too bad it wasn't enough to forgive the first three sins.

Plus 1 - Duke Nukem Forever retains the look of a Duke Nukem game looking a hundred times better.

Plus 2 - Duke keeps his orignal voice with it's orignal humor. Without that trademark now it wouldn't be a Nukem game.

Plus 3 - Duke retains his naughty ladies in the game except now in high res.

Plus 4 - His enemies never looked so good at being bad.

Now you are saying that the positives outnumber the mistakes. Realize my friend that those three basic mistakes completely change the dynamics and play of the game from Duke Nukem Meltdown that all the hard-core fans loved. Duke Nukem Forever only has a familiar face and voice of Duke but with the changes feels more like Master Chef or Chief or whatever that Halo character name is. Problem is it feels more like Halo than Nukem and as big as the Duke Nukem fan base was, lots of us were miffed to say the least. Personally I think Duke Nukem would of been better of doing Meltdown as a Retro Game than what they made with Forever. On a seperate note though, as miffed as I was at Nukem Forever, given time I got over my anger and like Duke Nukem too much to even let go of this sad excuse of a Nukem game. On that note I barely recommend this game but only because I find it hard to part with any Nukem game, even badly made ones.

Pros

Cons

reviewText: First of all, let me start with the technical aspect. By now the game has quite a few mediocre textures and models, it definately looks outdated. Add some bloom and blur with that, and you actually have a terrible looking game. And unfortunately, these options can't be turned off, so you're stuck with it for the entire game. The voice over of Duke is pretty decent, and the sound effects hold up well. But environments are bland and boring. The Duke references are ok and they do add to the atmosphere and the game doesn't take itself too seriously, thank God. Not that it matters in the end. It's a game that's just not worth the full price. Hell, had I known this all before I wouldn't have even bought it for more than €10. The few puzzles are decent, the combat is ok, the graphics are mediocre, it shows us nothing new and it just isn't any fun (one liners and conversations aside). I even had no expections so I'm extremely disappointed. Sorry Duke, but this is bargain bin material.\n\n[Rating: 62/100]

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever, the long awaited sequel to Duke Nukem 3D arrived 2,5 years ago.

Most people expected (a lot) more of this game and even though it's not far as good as Duke Nukem 3D was, I still think it's a decent game worth at least one playthrough.

Just like it's predecessor DNF is a FPS full of little jokes and mini-games. Things that would've been funny back in the days but things have changed. DNF still makes you giggle once in a while but for the main part the jokes are pretty silly and childish.

DNF tries to add a little story to the game which doesn't really add anything to the game and some of the maps can be very annoying, especially when playing on the hardest difficulty. It took me around 10 hours to finish the game on the 'Come Get Some' difficulty (the hardest mode except for Insane mode).

Even though DNF is not the game everyone was hoping for I'd still recommend it to anyone who can't get enough of Duke Nukem, FPS and childish humour.

reviewText: DNF may not be a bad game but it's really a bad duke nukem game. But still have to thank Gearbox for finishing this game although it's more of a nightmare. First, all the weapons feel like crap. None of the awesome weapons in the Duke Nukem 3d feel powerful in this game except railgun maybe. and you can only equip two weapons at a time. so most time you just have to run and gun like in most generic FPS. I mean it just does not feel like Duke nukem at all. The level design is not good either. Most encounters feel like playing a standard call of duty game which I clearly do not like. The only thing they manage to keep the theme of Duke Nukem with cheesy jokes. Overall this game is fun a few hours but quickly fun factors just fade away then it became a mediocre modern FPS. 3 out of 10.

reviewText:
Alright, I'm re-reviewing this. As somebody who has put 36 hours into the game and has gotten every single achievement for it, including the DLC stuff, I am fully qualified to make the most correct review of the game.

Pros: -

Cons: Duke Nukem Forever is like playing the history of first-person shooters, specifically the decade leading up to Duke Nukem Forever's release. Shades of Half-Life 1 and 2, Halo, Call of Duty, any game-changing FPS, all thrown into this game. Unforunately, it's all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ aspects of those games lazily mashed into an extremely boring and forgettable title. Limited amount of weapons on hand? Halo. Chest-high walls and cover shooting? Call of Duty. Physics puzzles and platforming? Half-Life 1/2. Level design that consists of linear hallways and the absence of exploration? Call of Duty. Vehicle segments? Half-Life 2 and Halo. Triggered events that play out when you reach certain parts of stages? Call of Duty and Half-Life 2. A lot of interactive environment fluff such as operating a microwave? Half-Life. Pipe bombs (grenades) and melee being a separate button? Call of Duty and Halo. Regenerating health? Call of Duty and Halo. Unskippable NPC dialog you have to listen to for story reasons before you can progress? Half-Life 1/2. I can go on and on. The game is a mish-mash of several concepts that first-person shooters have used as the genre evolved, and yet the game impliments them poorly. Nothing in the game is original, it's all borrowed ideas, the brainchild of George Broussard playing other video games and deciding to shove their original ideas into his game without wondering if it'll make Duke Nukem Forever better because of it. The writing is just as terrible and half-♥♥♥♥♥ as the rest of the game, which fluctuates between having outdated humor, stilted dialog, and occasional bouts of eerie misogyny that tries poorly to pass as jokes. The story is so disjointed that it feels like each chapter was written 2 years after the previous one, and it carries over to the level progression, where you jump from one environment to the next with no logical explaination as to why you are where you are now. And the gunplay wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't deliberately cribbed from Call of Duty wholesale, and with pacing even worse than Half-Life 2. Do you like walking down hallways, occasionally having to solve a physics puzzle, and then once you reach a room full of chest-high walls to use for cover, a bunch of aliens show up and you shoot it out with them, and then repeat your hallway/physics puzzle progression onto the next shootout? Because that makes up a good chunk of the game. And when they try to break it up with vehicle segments, they are, at minimum, twice as long as any vehicle segment in Half-Life 2, and with the same progression flow of drive to obstacle
recommended: shoot enemies until you get obstacle removal item
hoursPlayed: drive to next obstacle" that Half-Life 2 had. Nothing in this game is original. It's all cribbed from better games

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever is a first person shooter 15 years in the making. Back in the 90s most of us fell in love with Duke 3D. Not for its movie cliches or paying women for money, but for its non linear levels with a lot of exploration and guns. Well Duke Forever took away the non linear level design. Now Duke is stuck in some one dimensional levels. You'll visit the desert, a damn, a bar, an alien hive, his underground complex, get shrunk in a Duke Burger all on your journey to a tower. Duke isn't as fast as he used to be, so now he has vehicles every so often. You'll sit on and drive remote controlled cars and a giant monster truck that squashes enemies and uses nitrous boost for the jumps.

I think my issue with this game is the first two hours felt like everything but first person shooting. The game throws a lot of distractions at you. An interactive museum dedicated to Duke, punching, playing pinball, driving, first person platforming and a turret section. It just seemed like the shooting was 15% of what Duke Forever was.

Once you get over the giant hill of the first two hours, the game feels like a Half Life 2-ish game and that's good. Duke's world has been taken over by aliens. If it didn't sound Half-Life 2 enough for you, Duke walks and drives his way to a massive tower with a beam of light extending to the sky. There is a checkpoint system and no exploration or secrets. There are a few simple physics puzzles here and there. Moving barrels to weigh things down. Stuff like that.

The game uses a typical Unreal / Gearbox with controls to thumbstick crouch, thumbstick sprint (forward only), weapon switch, grenade, trip mine, zoom aim, fire, melee, jump and actions / reload. There are quick D-pad controls for Duke's night vision, holovision (duke clone to distract enemies), steroids and beer.

You can only carry 2 weapons and switch between them. There is a good variety of weapons. A laser sighted pistol, alien laser, shotgun, triple barreled ripper machinegun, rail gun to snipe, RPG, chaingun, devastator, freeze ray, triple stinger missile launcher, trip mines, grenades and so on. Nothing feels like it has impact.

The enemy intelligence is pretty good. Berserker pigs will charge, pig soldiers will shoot at you, and if you hide, they will grenade you. Alien soldiers hover, teleport in and out and actually try to flank you. It makes for a nice dynamic. The only problem is a lot of the maps are so straight forward, they don't allow for being flanked. The boss fights are pretty easy and that's not a complaint. Just RPG them until they're low on health, run to them and uh button mash them to death.

Other enemies from the franchise make their return. Octobrains swim, hover and shoot projectiles at you. Preginators jump and face stick onto you so you'll need to button mash to take them off. Hovering assault commanders that fire missiles at you. Overall, it seems like there aren't that many enemies, just different versions of them.

There are a few sections that confine you to an area and just have enemies flood in. It feels like a cheap way to extend gameplay, even if it does highlight enemy intelligence. Some enemy rooms are so simple that you see the enemy dropping in, so you can be there to shoot them point blank, taking away any kind of challenge or fun.

If this game wasn't Duke, I would have kept playing to realize there is an enjoyable game here past the first 2 hours.

reviewText:
It took 12 year's for the release of Duke Nukem Forever was it worth the wait ?
Maybe not but it's definitely not a pile of ♥♥♥♥ that people are calling it.

So here is the good:
- Gun are fun to use and have good sound effects
- You can carry up to 4 weapons at the time thanks to the support of Gearbox Software
- The interactive level like the strip club and the football field are fun and interesting in there level design
- Classic weapons from Duke3d are back which are fun to use
- Now you can increase the fov up to 120 thanks to the support of Gearbox Software
- A wannabe Half Life esque campaign vibe is appreciated
- lengthy Campaign up to 12 hrs of Gameplay
- Thank you Gearbox Software for finish what no one could

So here is the bad:
- Action set pieces are way too small for a Duke Game
- A lot of sexis element are present in the game which not surprising considering it's a Duke Nukem game but it could have been tackle in a smarter way
- Platforming is way too linear
- Texture work is a lot better on pc than it is on Ps3 and xbox 360 but still the game doesn't look good visually
- Unsatisfying Ending
- The railroad sequence are Uninspiring
- Multiplayer is Uninspiring
- Duke Nukem Forever is horribly optimised on console sadly

So at this point i don't need  to explain to you what went wrong during the development cycle that took 12 year you can look that up online. But i will say this people are just bashing this game just for the fun of it or they just played the console edition wich is a bad port.There are a lot really bad games in the FPS market and Duke Nukem Forever might not be a product of supreme quality that the Fans wanted but it is satisfying enough just so that it does not fall in to a total sheer of crap.

6.9/10 (Pc after Patches) 5.5/10 (Xbox 360 and Ps3)
Verdict: If you need to play this game then it is recommended on a steam sale and don't buy it on console.

PS: Randy Pitchfork instead of defending that horrible Alien Colonial Marins game that you like to call your Favorite Game you should focus on promoting a new Duke Nukem game instead.

reviewText:
When this finally came out, the general responce was that it was crap. So, I avoided it until this recent sale. I must say that the opposite is true. It would seem the nay-sayers were probably not born yet, or too young to play the originals, especially Duke3D, when it was the latest and greatest. Yes, there was a time when Duke3D was a techical marvel!

DNF is exactly what a sequel of Duke3D should be. But where Duke3D was rique, DNF is soft core porn.

The game has scores of references, is you look for them.

DNF is Duke3D and Half Life 2's love child...in a good way. DN's monster truck even sounds identical to the buggy in HL2.

DNF seems to avoid all of the single player FPS quagmires: There are no jumping puzzles, no cheap bosses, and only 1 very short conveyor-belt-with-pistons-of-death bit.

The major change is that health is now replaced by ego. Which replenishes after a time. This makes sense for the character and stops you running around avoid fights while looking for health like a wimp.

All in all, this game is brilliant.

reviewText:
Do you want to play a first person shooter with memorable enemies, terrific level design, engaging gunplay and most of all: personality?

Then play a different game, preferably Duke Nukem 3D.

Sure, Duke is as hilarious of a character as ever and no punches are pulled as far as ridiculous humor goes, but it hardly matters when he's thrown into a ♥♥♥♥-poor, rough draft of a video game. You'll find yourself chuckling occasionally while pulling your hair out over the god-awful driving, terrible level design that belongs in no game released after 2005-- and speaking of 2005; graphics that look on par with an Xbox 360 launch title.

Play literally anything else. If this was named anything else and had nothing to do with such an iconic character, this game would not even have the slightest cult following.

Avoid this like the plague, or in other words; avoid this like it's Duke Nukem Forever.

reviewText: One of the most despised games in existence, and for good reason. Duke Nukem Forever begins with the best of intentions, and the first hour or so is actually moderately entertaining. But in short order, what begins as a dead average first-person shooter degenerates into a series of platform jumping puzzles with little in the way of actual combat or action between them. A drought of weapons simply highlights the fact that this game is a shooter in name only. Progression means enduring one stale problem-solving exercise after another, occasionally punctuated by a horrible boss fight. By the time you realize that these aren't just intermittent elements but are in reality the entire game, you think you've sunk in enough time already and that the game will be over soon, so you press on. But the game doesn't end. It plods on so ridiculously far past the point where an ending would have been a welcome reprieve and only becomes less bearable as the player's patience wears thinner and thinner. For sure, Duke Nukem Forever earns a lot of scorn simply because as a long-awaited entry to an otherwise great franchise, it fell far short of lofty expectations. But the game is horrible even when you try to set it aside from its predecessors and analyze it on its own precious few merits. The fact that this frustrating, disjointed abortion probably killed an otherwise good series off only adds a slightly superficial complaint to a long list of valid reasons to hate Duke Nukem Forever with the intensity of a thousand suns.

reviewText:
I recommend this game. I honestly suspected that with all the bad reviews this would perhaps not be an enjoyable experience, but I'm glad this was not the case.

The above said, there are some things that sort of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off - such as what seems like console tilted experience over the original PC experience that was Duke Nukem. I assume if it wasn't we might have seen the return of the 'mighty foot' as an actual action - though it only returns as a suped up mega-truck.

Another thing I sort of disliked was the fact that the game felt too much like Half Life or Portal - I didn't come to play this game for the puzzles with a side of alien killing now. While the puzzles were sometimes interesting and fun, there was simply too many of them.

Outside of general game design though, I didn't find myself hating a whole lot about the game itself. Some things could definetely have been better - like the mini-games, I certainly wouldn't have minded perhaps seeing an animated cue stick while playing pool for example.

Overall though, this is a decent game that is worth playing if you have some time to kill.

reviewText:
I recommend this game. I honestly suspected that with all the bad reviews this would perhaps not be an enjoyable experience, but I'm glad this was not the case.

The above said, there are some things that sort of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off - such as what seems like console tilted experience over the original PC experience that was Duke Nukem. I assume if it wasn't we might have seen the return of the 'mighty foot' as an actual action - though it only returns as a suped up mega-truck.

Another thing I sort of disliked was the fact that the game felt too much like Half Life or Portal - I didn't come to play this game for the puzzles with a side of alien killing now. While the puzzles were sometimes interesting and fun, there was simply too many of them.

Outside of general game design though, I didn't find myself hating a whole lot about the game itself. Some things could definetely have been better - like the mini-games, I certainly wouldn't have minded perhaps seeing an animated cue stick while playing pool for example.

Overall though, this is a decent game that is worth playing if you have some time to kill.

reviewText: Ok this game is....not what i had in mind. I may be 18 years old but i used to play alot of old computer games like doom, Duke Nukem and Postal were my personal favorites. The Game play is... ok, the graphics were fine which led me wondering why people gave it a bad review, when i played it i felt as if this was not even considered a Duke Nukem game.... I Fell if this game were to have someone else in it instead of Duke this would be a fantastic game, however 3d Realms kept delaying and now we got this. As a fan this game is not worth it, you will be really disappointed, For several reasons like the ability to kick your enimies is gone, duke barley talks to ayone interacting with him, he canonly carry two weapons, and those are like Duke's greatest assets, you take that away from him and you just have some blond a-hole Duke wannabe running around i am sorry to say. It was a good thing i tried this game for myself, the same thing happened with Postal 3 people hated so much but when i played it, i felt at home, with Duke Nukem forever i felt like i wasn't even playing as Duke. For someone who has never heard of Duke Nukem before this game would be ok for you to buy, but any Duke Nukem fans... i fell it's not worth it but thats only my opion over all it is a pretty sharp game.

reviewText:
You have no idea how much time I put into Duke Nukem 3D as a child, hundreds and hundreds of hours, on more than one platform. Duke Nukem 3D helped shape the FPS genre. It's totally fair to say Duke Nukem Forever had some serious shoes to fill.

You have no idea how much I ♥♥♥♥ing wanted to love this game.

I badly wanted, nay, badly needed to love this game! and the good news - it is a fun game. In parts.

The game opens with you replaying the classic 1996 Football field Boss Fight. As the one liners start flowing I breathe a sigh of relief. it's clear they haven't missed the mark too much, but this leads to one of Duken Nukem Forevers' core problems.

It hasn't advanced much at all since the 90's.

Maybe this was the point you may say, but I don't think so. Duke pokes fun at moderns shooters then uses features taken directly from them, such as an Unlimited regenerating health pool and only being able to carry two weapons at any given time.

You can't take the ♥♥♥♥ out of a game then directly use features from it.

At it's core Duken Nukem Forever is an old school run and gun game. The levels have little coherence and could just as easily be a selection of random events that Duke comes into shooting and shouting one liners.

There are good parts, the combat is entertaining and has a 'classic' feel, the weapons are fun to use (even with overly large models) there are lots naked women, Duke ripping aliens heads off, Ball punching, Beer drinking, and crude humor that the child in me did enjoy.

Huge mini boss encounters are also fun but then you are soon back to some filler moment, when all you really want to do is blow up more aliens with a Rocket launcher.

To it's credit this game has no cut scenes. everything happens through the eyes of Duke. This is important, and I'd like to see more of this 'Half Life' approach in other FPS's.

The really bad moments in the game come from a driving level, broken up with a pointless Oh no I've run out of gas" moment... and horrible and unavoidable control a shooting turret sections
date:
mixed wioth lots of filler moments.

You have no idea how much I ♥♥♥♥ing wanted to love this game.
Duke - it's great to have you back
recommended: but this isn't the game we deserved."

reviewText:
It's bad. Read on if you dare.


It's even more puerile than Duke Nukem 3D, and with even less relevance. When 3D was released in early '96, at least that game's aesthetic was an earnest step in a new direction: video gaming entering its adolescence. It may not have been particularly tasteful or mature, but at least it was a better direction than the tired, cynical, even-more-over-the-top toxic masculinity and objectification of women on display in DNF.

The developers eventually said that their world-building was genius because everyone in-universe takes it completely seriously. It more often comes across as tired, aggressively moronic, disgusting, or a combination thereof. On the rare occasion the writing manages to rise above that, it's still usually not great. In 3D, this sort of stuff, while still a bit cringeworthy, ultimately played second fiddle to the great gameplay. Here, the gameplay seems like it plays second fiddle in both quality and importance.

The only plus I can give the writing is that it's an unwitting dystopia. Duke Nukem is our hero for saving humanity multiple times as Homo sapiens is more vulnerable than ever. We see massive monuments erected in his honor, awards bestowed, his own fast food chain, and even a dedicated Las Vegas casino complex. Thanks to his hero status, everyday people are emulating his forceful personality enough that American society has become more aggressive and sexist.


DNF makes its alien invasion story feel tiring more quickly than it has a right to. There's a couple characters here and there, primarily Duke's friend General Graves and his boss, the less-than-perceptive US President. You'll see the plot 'twist' concerning him a mile away. Captain Dylan the infantry commander is notable for how vulgar he is. The rest are either unremarkable or cannon-fodder, with two in particular I'll get to soon.

There are a couple inspired touches, but they're needles in a haystack. For example, whenever Duke is knocked down or kicks open a door, the animation and camerawork is pretty nicely synced - and it's satisfying to kick open doors here. The dynamic, breakable lighting is also a nice touch, as is keyboard navigation in the menus ala 3D.

Then you see another low-quality texture that might have flown in 2004 and you remember what game you're playing. I mean the graphics aren't the worst thing about this game by far, but they stand out pretty early as a sign of things to come. It makes DNF seem like a prolonged boxing match between the power of human talent and the ravages of time.


The writing reaches its nadir in the alien hive, about midway through the game. Here we have - trigger warning, folks - rather graphic depictions of sexual violence against women by the alien invaders. Yeah, I know this kinda happened in 3D too, but it wasn't nearly as graphic or tasteless. There, it usually fit into the quiet terror of Episode 2's levels. Here in DNF, we still hear Duke snarking like nothing is out of the ordinary.

Soon you come across two characters that were never more than one-dimensional parodies and servile sex objects for Duke, and this is the important part, right up to their final painful moments. Then we come across alien boobs embedded in a wall which Duke can play with and snark about while women scream in pain and horror all around him. The most he can do for them is mercy-kill them while unconvincingly stating it's 'better this way'. The whole thing is, and I'm saying this with remarkable charity, not the best fit for a parodic series about a manly dude blowing ♥♥♥♥ up and and obsessing over babes.


Now, the gameplay.

It is largely derivative of Half-Life and Halo, but not as good. Most of the game was dated when it came out, really. Maybe if you're a 'retro gamer' you can appreciate that, but sometimes you'll still feel this game should have came out at least 6 years before it did.

DNF's gunplay is serviceable enough not to be totally awful, although it really is more Halo than Duke. The option to carry four weapons (because 'Duke isn't Halo!') makes the game easier at the cost of destroying what little verisimilitude it had. It's hilarious when Duke literally wishes out loud that he had three guns late in the game.

My favorite weapon was actually the pistol, a relatively modest weapon that rewarded accuracy. Most of the other guns felt sloppy and unsatisfying, although the shotgun deserved credit for having stopping power. The aiming and movement are off, too. Occasionally the movement gels really well with what's going on but oftentimes it's just weird.


I was initially surprised by how quickly I was progressing through the campaign, but there's a decent amount there - enough frustration and filler, at least. It took me around 10 hours the first time on Hard difficulty. Some of the puzzles and player directioning hint at competence on the design team, but not enough of it got through. There's enough world interactivity to match DN3D, but without the benefit of being new or unique.

The game's structure is a far cry from 3D's open levels, which would be forgivable if it was good. DNF's story may be in the background, but it's ultimately more of a driving force than 3D's. Said predecessor is masterful in comparison, building off DOOM with its labryinthine levels and even less intrusive plot. DNF really wants to be more like Half-Life 2, with linear progression supplemented by spoonfuls of plot" and even vehicle sections.

Those sections aren't the worst driving I've ever had
date: like how a leftover $1.50 pizza bagel isn't the worst snack you'll ever eat. It certainly can't make up for long loading times & small level sizes comparable to Invisible War in their ridiculousness.\n\nOverused QTE events
hoursPlayed: routine boss fights
voteText: annoying enemies and encounters that border on unplayably difficult round out DNF's list of features. The Grand Canyon-esque difficulty spikes in those battles indicate a lack of playtesting. For a game that took 15 years to make.\n\nIn fairness
helpfulPercent: the final level & boss battle was surprisingly decent. The giant Enforcer-versus-mini Duke battle was also inspired
votesHelpful:
even if you had to juke it to actually win.

Ladder climbing is probably the most interesting thing in the entire game: you press a key to get on and you actually climb the things. It sacrifices a bit of juking potential for actual ease of use.


The way you increase your regenerating health (or "ego") is interesting
votesTotal: but ultimately I don't care for it. Even when it becomes a blessing on harder difficulties
votesFunny: you still have to run away from combat to regenerate. It adds to my feeling that Duke is more vulnerable and washed up than he thinks he is
commentsCount: whether he knows it or not. It also gave the devs a big excuse to mash Call of Duty's influence into their potpourri of a campaign
column16: but I digress.\n\nMultiplayer is old school 'run for the biggest guns' with a small but apparently dedicated playerbase. The starting pistol at least proved powerful enough that I didn't die all the time to the weird hit detection
column17:
because the weird hit detection also worked in my favor. The My Digs feature might have been interesting if it wasn't partly sexist and if the game was good enough to play and unlock stuff.


DNF is a big disappointment if your expectations are anywhere above the level of 'budget shooter'. Duke was a product of a specific time
column18: a vehicle that didn't need to be revived so acrimoniously to create what is essentially a parody of action blockbusters by way of Adam Sandler. You should only even consider buying this if it's heavily discounted and if you're a series completionist or masochist."
