reviewText: The only game that has taken 14 years to finish. Whether it's good or not doesn't even matter! This is HISTORY. The game leaves a lot to be desired, and a lot of the design choices that were made hinder the game's ability to live up to potential. The game is still completely playable, and still has some unique experiences to offer. I think the game is at least a solid 6/10, but my bias for the Duke franchise brings it up to a 6.5.

votesTotal: but ultimately I don't care for it. Even when it becomes a blessing on harder difficulties
votesFunny: you still have to run away from combat to regenerate. It adds to my feeling that Duke is more vulnerable and washed up than he thinks he is
commentsCount: whether he knows it or not. It also gave the devs a big excuse to mash Call of Duty's influence into their potpourri of a campaign
column16: but I digress.\n\nMultiplayer is old school 'run for the biggest guns' with a small but apparently dedicated playerbase. The starting pistol at least proved powerful enough that I didn't die all the time to the weird hit detection
column17:
because the weird hit detection also worked in my favor. The My Digs feature might have been interesting if it wasn't partly sexist and if the game was good enough to play and unlock stuff.


DNF is a big disappointment if your expectations are anywhere above the level of 'budget shooter'. Duke was a product of a specific time
column18: a vehicle that didn't need to be revived so acrimoniously to create what is essentially a parody of action blockbusters by way of Adam Sandler. You should only even consider buying this if it's heavily discounted and if you're a series completionist or masochist."

reviewText: Full of nostalgia! All of this negative reviews from game critics? WTF? The graphics aren't top of the line and the aiming is a bit squirrely at times. However, this is a great break from the cookie cutter COD style FPS main stream that critics only want to see, I guess. I found myself literally laughing out loud throughout the entire game. With all the minigames and interactive props it was a game inside the game itself. I mean you can even pick up wet turds out of toilets and ♥♥♥♥ in monsters eyes, to which duke has something to say about that! The voice acting is wonderful and hilarious. This is not a game that takes itself seriously and provided a much needed break from the norm FPS for me. If you have a sense of humor and/or have played and enjoyed the original do not hesitate to buy this game. Lots of cool extras once you beat the game. I have not played the multiplayer, but it itself is interactive and has its own storyline. Hail to the king baby!

reviewText: Nice game but it was too short. Each levels lasts about 10 min of play. I remember playing Half-life and the levels were huge and contunious and it lasted for 3 months. Duke lasted for 1 week. Duke can only hold 2 weapons unless you turn on an option and then he can hold 4. Ok, so that isn't a big deal. I very much liked the nudity and language (not many games have it). The AI is weak. Graphics are great, but pretty much all games have the same graphics these days. I hate the heckpoint thing. Multiplayer is fun. Will there be another Duke? Perhaps in 24 years when I'm an old man.

reviewText: IT'S DUKE!!!.  ok that out of the way , i must say this game took a rather unfair bashing in the press.  Most game reviewers gave it a 50  for numerous reasons , such as mediocre level design,  adding nothing new to the genre , and my favorite one to discuss , , duke's attitude.  Yes people, stupid game reviewers actually blasted DNF because duke acted more like duke than he ever did before .  Mysoginistic ?  not really imo, male shovanistic, definitely.  insulting to gays , women , or any one that wasn't a strait alpha male .. most definitely it is duke after all.  does that magically make the game less fun .. no.  on the average the reviewers were right about the level design , most of it is a bit mediocre  but many parts jump out as sheer classic fun . If you loved the original duke , and you arnt shy about humor , give this game a try. I give it a solid 70% out of 100%

reviewText: I remember seeing this game at E3 and shouting in my personal space, then it released... The game makes up for the loss in good Dukenukem games, but not for the loss in years it took to make, if that makes any sense. This is pretty much the same game we played back in the days, but with beautiful HD graphics. If you are looking for something new and different about Duke you are better off going back in time and buying the 3000 expantion pack for the original game. I recommend this game for those fans who will buy the game even if it sucked, you know you would.

reviewText:
It's not the worst game in the world, on it's own merits it is a pretty fun First Person Shooter with a lot of Interactive environments, which is big considering many games nowadays don't have those small little interactive vending machines... If you have ever played Half Life 1 or 2 there were vending machines which you could interact with, and that small little interaction with the world made it feel much more alive. I like interactive elements in First Person Shooters and this interactive element in FPS games seems to have died out.

Anyways, this game opens up with you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in a urinal. What the hell?
Next, you grab feces out of a toilet and then throw it at the wall. What on earth?
After that, you refine someone's plan by drawing a phallus. Why?
To top it all off, you kick an alien's eyeball into a field goal while it's raining.

That is the opening sequence, and I think it is supposed to be a showcase as to how much technology has progressed and how graphics have come a long way, but good graphics don't make a good game. (I'm looking at you Crytek lol)

Warning: This game has tons of random boobage. Don't get me wrong, I like boobs, but why would you just have random TnA everywhere? The original Duke Nukem 3d didn't have this much crude nudity and sex jokes, if not any if I recall.
Oh, if we're going to compare Duke Nukem Forever to Duke Nukem 3d, let's talk about some things that totally should have been in Duke Nukem Forever but were not in Duke Nukem Forever.

Mighty Foot (You cannot press a button to kick)
Unequipping / The ability to punch whenever and where ever (You cannot holster and start socking aliens in the groin ;_;)
Non-existant weapon limit (Duke Nukem Forever has a 4 or 2 weapon limit, there is an option to increase it to a 4 weapon limit, but there is still a limit.)
Now onto things that simply should have been in Duke Nukem Forever but are not in Duke Nukem Forever. (Features exclusive to DNF and stuff)

Nudity toggle (There's random boobage, don't expect any let's plays from this game! Heh)
Dynamic cutscene skip (I understand why this can be difficult to implement, but oh my god I hate sitting through a cutscene" of two snotty twins talking to the player.)
Advanced graphics options (Hey look I can toggle post-processing effects
date: not really. I am only toggling SOME post processing effects
recommended: also I want to control which post-processing effects I want and I want to choose the level of quality of these effects
hoursPlayed: and I also want to be able to configure shadow resolution and distance
voteText: and I want a pony. >.<  )\n--Inventory (This is IF you have added more and more items for the player to hold
helpfulPercent: but there's only a few "special things" other than weapons the player can hold. Beer
votesHelpful: steroids
votesTotal: and a hologram projection of the player. I marked this with two dashes as a "What if".)\nHey did I mention you can throw antiques at humanoid boars? Yeah you can throw antiques at topless alien boar roid-addicts with 8-packs and they get on all fours and chase you like a werewolf and then they'll try and pounce on you

-

reviewText:
Good game with pretty good levels, some of which just fall short due to illogic and invisible walls, but the majority of which are well-designed and flow equally well.  Loading times are another con, but they don't punctuate playtime too heavily.  Perhaps the greatest perk about the game is that it incorporates platforming in a usually non-invasive way, which gives it a suitably retro feel -- also, fun weapon selection: the devestator, freeze ray, and shrink ray all have a nice, cartoony feel to them.

Many none-too-subtle references to pop and gaming culture as well as common fourth-wall jokes to be found both in level design and in dialogue.  Duke's not an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, he's a macho-man, and he's secure enough not to project his insecurities onto those around him.

Good game, good character, but can be damn frustrating and for no good reason.

reviewText:
No game ever will live up to 12+ years of development, that is impossible.  The game is tremendously under rated.  The campaign does start out a little slow aside from 1 encounter and it's really not the same style as Duke3D, but it's the same spirit and humor.  Where Duke3D took the FPS concept and made it better, Duke Forever didn't have nearly the impact on the genre that Duke3D did.  Success it not easily repeated.

The Doctor Who Cloned Me:
If you even somewhat enjoyed the campaign for Duke Nukem Forever then you should buy this, it starts off right where the campaign ended and it adds a heafty amount of gameplay for the money.  You can really see where the developers that the developers improved on what they already had.  The game just seemed to flow better, in terms of combat sequences, sections of finding things to boost your ego bar.

Multiplayer:
Aside from the occasional lag and the hackers, this part of the game is extremely fun.  It's fast paced, aggressive, and there is the Jetpack.  There are plenty of maps especially if you get the DLC.  Everyone is on equal ground, it's multiplayer plays slightly like Quake, weapon spawns, power ups.  Back in the 90's when this game was announced I wasn't even thinking about buying this game for the multiplayer, but what a gem it turned out to be.  Most of my multiplayer playtime came when I owned a copy of this on the PS3, but I have played some on the PC too.  I loved it so much when I stopped playing I was top 15 in the world on PS3, I'm sure by now I've dropped off the top 100 but it was great times.


When considering if this game is any good you have to consider it as a whole, did you have fun playing it at any point?  Ignore the fact that it was in development for so long and forget about the way Duke3D was, we all know how great Duke3D is, and no Duke Forever is not better than Duke3D, but it's still way more original that many of the other FPS that get released now a day.

Game was released a few years ago, last regular price I saw was $40.00
Not a great price for it, I recommend picking it up on a sale.  I feel like anything over 20 for a game this old is too high, for any title.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a hard one to talk about... DN3D is one of my favorite games ever. From its over macho sense of humor, to just phenomenal level design. You can't beat 1997 Duke.

First off you have to understand no game EVER is going to live up to 13 years of hype. It should be considered a miracle that this game even is out at this point.

singleplayer:
The game starts off slow... VERY SLOW. For a old school shooter sequel there isn't any shooting for at least a hour into the game. Really got annoying after awhile. Then the 4 weapon limit... argh. Just not fun when you're not a walking tank in a Duke Nukem game.

The guns also feel very floaty. Not a lot of bang except for the shotgun, and even that started to lose its fun in the end game.  The levels were also very very very linear, with no freedom of execution like in DN3D. That in itself should be considered a sin.

Interaction with your environment is still pretty insane, though most if its pretty useless/not funny. Boobs are still here, but they aren't as magical as they were to a 13 year old me. The game does also push the boundaries of sexual content, to the point where I shut down the game near one of the bosses due to a grotesque death sequence.

Ultimately The whole game felt very stiff and artificial. It's simply not Duke.


Multiplayer:

pretty decent! Fun while it lasts, but isn't anything special. Mini Dukes everywhere!

I really wanted to like this game. i really did, but i can't lie, it's just not Duke. There is still a wee bit of a nostalgia factor. This game proves that Duke is a character truly lost in an era. Only get if in a cheap sale.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
With all the bad press i'd heard I thought if this game at least achieved a par as a first person shooter I could live with it, but it falls pathetically short at even that.

I don't know where to begin with the dissapointments. The game starts sort of fast enough, reliving a boss battle from a previous game, but it get's so slow and pathetic and you spend the next half hour walking around pushing buttons and solving p*ssweak mini puzzles before anything begins to happen.

May as well stick to melee combat for the next half hour after that, because the first two weapons you get are p*ssweak and innacurate, punching an enemy twice will kill him, but shooting him five times will not, even at point blank range headshots often fail to register.

They seeming spent so much effort making fun little nick nacks and mini games and all these tiny things you can do in the game.. but there's almost no game in between them, the fights are reduced to a series of killing two enemies, two more appear, kill them and another two appear, kill a final two and the sequence is over and you move forward on your linear path. Believe me as well, fighting 2 enemies four times is being light, the sequences go on even longer the further you progress. have fun fighting the same 2 enemies 18 times in a single area, GLORIOUS. The combat isn't ever fun at any point.

I'm not going to write too much further, this game has almost made me angry, the characters are a sick joke, even poor Duke is reduced to a brainless f*ckwit, what piece of sh*t wrote the script? How much ice was he smoking?
Personally I'm rooting for the aliens, who the hell would want to save these braindead a**holes.

Even if this is on sale, save your $5 for anything else. I'd be so up for a refund right now, I'd go right out and get some hot chips and a coke... I know it's bad for me, but I wont have to wait 14 years for it and it's garenteed to leave a better taste in my mouth.

Rest in peace Duke.

reviewText:
When I bought my first 486dx pc way way back in 1995 one of the few games I used to love playing was Doom. Then, in early 1996, someone gave me the shareware of Duke Nukem 3D and I was hooked. Played that 1st level about 3 times before the full game was released. What an awsome game and still is today.

Some years later I signed up to the 3DRealms formum to up with developments on the new and upcoming DNF. As you can imagine I was there quite some time and eventually after about 8 years decided it wasn't going to happen.

Then, out of the blue, it was suddenly here. Duke Nukem Forever. I couldn't believe it. I even pre-ordered which is something I've never done before. What a fanboy ;-).

It arrived, I installed, I played. And I continued to play in the vain hope that what I was experiencing would get better. It had to... after all those years of waiting it simply had to.

But it didn't, did it..it stayed sh!t throughout the whole game. I can honectly say I have never ever been so dissappointed in a game.

Do NOT buy this game it is pure sh!t and I wouldn't buy this game at all, in fact you couldn't give it away for free.

reviewText: I remember when this came out, and a lot of people hated it. They said it wasn't the duke they remember. Fair enough.  With that being said, I'm liking this game.  To be honest, I never played any of the previous duke games.I never really had an interest, until now. only two things I do not care for: 1. The puzzles:While I was able to figure all of them out, having to play through all of them did get tedious, for me, at least. At times, I had to quit the game, and search youtube, to find out how to solve some of them. Case in point, the first puzzle, the huge Duke Statue. 2:While I can understand an occasional f-bomb now and again, do we really need them in a lot of the dialouge? Yes, this is Duke, and like I said, while I never played any of the past duke games, was there a need to show him having the mouth of a trucker in this? All in all, this is a solid game, with ok graphics, a cheesy story, etc. If your looking for a game to kill some time(no pun intended), and do not mind f-bombs, solving puzzles(some do take time to figure out, as mentioned before), then this may be the game for you.

reviewText:
Underrated.This game has gotten outlandishly low ratings because the majority of people have no idea how to keep their expectations in check. Stop getting hyped people, expect what you can expect, not what you think the trailer promises or what you would like to see in the game.

Of course, this game is far from perfect and doesn't even come close to what it could have been, but in the end, it's a new Duke Nukem game and I, for one, am happy it's here. It's Duke Nukem. Stop comparing the game to similar titles because similar titles do NOT have Duke Nukem. Why don't people recognize that the entertainment value of this game hinges entirely on the character itself? Duke Nukem has always had a cult following. You either bet on Duke or you don't.

You can not enjoy this game if you're not in on the concept of what Duke Nukem means.
If you're not a fan of the character, this game has absolutely nothing to offer to you.


Stop hating, Duke is love, Duke is life.
Hail to the king, baby.

PS: To any critic that gave this game a 1/10 or similar, you are a spoiled little child and rate games based on how they compare to your expectations, rather than their intrinsic entertainment value. Go die. You're literally doing the opposite of a good job.

reviewText: The only way to truly enjoy this game is to pretend that it's not related to Duke Nukem 3D, and to not be familiar with old-school shooters like Doom or Quake. The biggest problem with DNF is that it claims to be a callback to the old days of gaming, and yet the end result is a modernized mess that just tried to do too many things at once. As a result, there's some people that call it dated, and some that call it too modernized. It simply pleases nobody - not classic Duke fans, or modern FPS fans.\n\nStill, there's a tiny bit of hope that someday, Duke will return as the great 90s gaming icon he once was. It just isn't the time yet.

reviewText:
I didn't expect a good game. I expected a Duke Nukem game. I didn't get either.

I've always been a Duke Nukem 3D fan because it was my first game I've ever played. I've played countless hours of DN3D through the years and was finally hyped for DNF. I've preordered DNF and even thought about getting myself the Balls Of Steel Edition. I've counted every day, hour and minute for its release. When it was finally released, nothing else in the world did matter.

I finished the game in just ONE sitting, in the hardest setting. Got 60% of the achievements in one swoop. I wasn't even rushing, I was taking my time to enjoy the game. I was dazed and confused. What went wrong?

Well, I got it down what went wrong AS A DUKE NUKEM GAME:

- The game offers no challenge whatsoever. Everything feels easy.
- I could only use two guns per time. TWO guns. Screw you, you're only holding 2 guns at a time.
- The game is linear. No keycards, no switches, nothing. Just straight forward.
- No puzzles. I only got like one or two of these and they weren't memorable. You won't be spending your time with them.
- The level design is just awful. As I said, the game is a corridor, so don't expect those rooms and layers you're used to on a normal Duke Nukem game.
- The soundtrack didn't seem fitting. I miss that bassy MIDI songs.
- Health recovery like CoD or Halo games killed 50% of the fun. You won't be begging for medikits, you just get behind a cover and wait.
- Gun impact felt bland. Gunplay was very dull.
- Shooting sections feel cheap. They lock the room and throw enemies at you. That's pretty much it.

And what went right:

+ I like the new guns.
+ Multiplayer was a fun mode but it was condemned since day one.
+ It's Duke Nukem. He's that guy full of one liners and wrong jokes.


But that's about it. Duke Nukem Forever feels and plays like a unfinished and unpolished game. It feels like a beta through the whole game. Get it for REALLY CHEAP if you're a hardcore fan, if not then just don't.

reviewText:
My first experience with Duke was when he was kicking butt left ways and right as a platform side scroller. 1996 introduce us to the Iconic Duke 3D,.  Universally praised and a real high point in Duke's gaming career.

However the same can not be said for Duke Nukem Forever (DNF) or as i just aptly call it Duke Nukem Forget it.  The game is  more crass than class and the fun which was there in the previous games is missing.

The second DLC pack The Doctor Who Cloned Me does make great strides in trying to rectify a lot of the problems in DNF and probably a better starting point to playing the game if you happen to own the base game.
- 4 out of 10 Kiwifruit.  C'mon Gearbox fix this slide.

reviewText:
I recently finished Super Castlevania IV for the first time and have come to the conclusion that Duke Nukem Forever is not a good game.

After playing Castlevania IV I was hugely impressed by the ability to whip in 8 different directions in comparison to the normal 4 and I thought this was a huge leap in innovation for the gaming industry. As a result, when I first decided to play Duke Nukem Forever (a game which was released 20 years after Castlevania IV) I expected to see the same innovative ideas. To my shock (and horror) I discovered that Duke Nukem Forever does not feature 8 directional-whips, in fact, Duke Nukem Forever doesn't have whips at all! This was most disappointing because I was really looking forward to whipping in 16 different directions but maybe 20 years isn't enough to create digital whips that whip in that many directions.

Whereas Castlevania IV has the player advance through various themed (and spooky) stages until you arrive at Dracula's Lair and defeat him in a climactic end to the only good Castlevania game, Duke Nukem Forever has you save American pornstars from Kotaku writers. Personally I think that saving the world from Dracula is more important than saving American pornstars but I am not a cis-gendered feminist so what do I know.

In conclusion I would recommend Super Duke Nukem IV over Castlevania Forever because there are a lot of innuendos and sexual jokes about ♥♥♥♥♥♥s and those are my favourite types of jokes.

reviewText:
You have extra money, that you want spend on a game? It's not this one, go rather give them to a random homeless man on the street.
This game is a total failure, I've played two hours and thirty minutes- it was enough to make a verdict for this game. I feel ashamed for me and 12 of my friends who bought this game. This game is a total failure at all points:
a) Storyline- bad, some tale about aliens that invaded the Earth.
b) Gameplay- Well, there's nothing more then running and gunning, even CoD gameplay is more interesting than this.
c) Graphics- This game was released in 2011, but even for those times- graphics are bad, really bad. Take Battlefield 3 for an example (It also was released in 2011)
d) Humor (The thing, for what all we loved Duke Nukem)- Dead and gone, jokes are bad and not funny.
Well are those 4 points enough to you, to prove, that this game isn't worth even 1$? Please, trust me, don't waste your time and money on this.
3/10 (Why not 1? Just for the old times)

reviewText:
Okay, yeah, this game has a lot of flaws. There are noticable weird stuff like monsters ragdolling after being shot and stuff like that. And - yeah, it's cheesy as hell.

But the thing is - it's Duke Nukem. He is a badass, he has his trademark one-liners, he knows who he is. And it just feels good to be a badass. It feels good to be Duke Nukem, to just kill everything with some ridiculous guns. And what I like most about this game - is that it's not serious, and it knows it. God dammit, those aliens steal and impregnate our women - how the hell is that supposed to be serious?

And for this - I like this game. It kinda even feels like old Duke Nukem (well, compared to modern military simulators"). Many people would disagree - but I enjoyed this game. It's great
date: and if you can ignore first 30 minutes of "what the hell?" - you may probably like it too."

reviewText:
The King is Back! I thought the king decided to join the land of vaporware. Seriously, I am glad they released this after 15 years of development but by the time this installment of the Duke Nukem series was released I had already gotten bored of this franchise.

You have all the jokes there, really, all kinds of references that made the first Duke FPS very original and truly entertaining. You have the pig police officers and other bad guys you remember and your favourite weapons from the predecessor also return.

Yet, for me this game really felt like an afterthought. I believe Duke should have never been woken up from his long cryo-sleep. Only pick this one up if you are truly a Duke fan. But if you are a true Duke fan, why don't you purchase the Megaton Edition of the classic instead of wasting money and time on this one?

UPDATE: I have played some more recently. Did some achievement hunting as well as completed the last 2 levels I'd missed before as I'd simply stopped playing years ago. It did not get much more exciting - Duke Nukem Forever is fun, but it's still a mediocre shooter that should have been left unfinished.

reviewText:
Recommend on sale below $10.

Single player is fun. The 4 weapon system is fine with me, since borderlands also did 4 weapons. Most bosses have to be taken down by explosives and turrets. No mighty boot, but you can smack your enemies with your gun. The handgun, shotgun and railgun are my favorite weapons. The game is split in killing all the enemies, puzzles, driving, and boss fights.

Multiplayer is corrupted with hackers, but there are some good runs. Multiplayer is also corrupted with toxic people, (Alessio/Frau Blucher) that point at people of being hackers just because they got killed once. He would then leave the game, and load his hacks and come back to be a jerk. Living in North America, the servers are mostly laggy (~200 ping) because most of the players are from Sweden or Austrailia.

You can level up in multiplayer which upgrades your dig, do challenges and unlock wearable items. You unlock chicks in your dig when you can talk to. Challenges are best way imo to level up, stuff like Kill X amounts of players with Y gun" or " Run X miles." You can customize your Duke in multiplayer with the wearing items i.e. 3D glasses

reviewText: It's as bad as people have said. The graphics were dated upon release with some textures being worse than textures found in the original Half Life, having regenerating health in the same game that he mocks power armor, a limit on how many guns you can hold in a Duke Nukem game of all things, poorly slapped in jump puzzles, minigames with some of the worst physics you will ever see, humor on par with a Happy Madison production, bosses requiring a certain weapon making your already limited held weapons even less, weak writing, cringeworthy puns, showing that Duke gets wasted after a single beer, and more.\n\nThis game would have been better off cancelled instead of wasting 14 years trying to get this game released. Oh and it takes jabs at Valve's puzzles while at the same time having some of the worst puzzles in gaming. If you truly want to play a Duke Nukem game, let it be any one but this one.

reviewText: Duke Nukem Forever is not one of the worst games I've ever played. That is me trying to be as objective as possible. The game was in development for years and drove it's parent company 3D Realms completely out of business. I followed it like a hawk and was extremely disappointed with what little Gearbox did to it.\n\nDuke Nukem Forever has a lot of flaws and many people incorrectly assume it's because Duke Nukem is outdated". Infact if this game had been a Serious Sam style old school first person shooter
date: I would be defending it til the day I die. That is not what this game is at all. It has all the outdated elements of Duke Nukem 3D along with a lot of modern concessions. While the game does implement new elements to the design they tend to fall flat. You have new weapons you don't use
recommended: new quotes you don't enjoy and new elements you dislike. What we get is regenerating health
hoursPlayed: and a two weapon limit. Yes Duke needs to hide behind cover and stop feeling depressed when he gets shot.\n\nThe game is certainly not unplayable
voteText: fully patched it runs at a stable framerate with FOV options. Since it's an U3 game it generally shouldn't have too many bugs. It's just not the game we wanted and that's what utterly kills me with it. It doesn't appeal to new players and it alienates old ones.\n\nI actually feel the one thing Gearbox could have done to fix all this was to add modding support to the game. Duke Nukem 3D had a very large map editing community that still survives to this day. Fans could have created their own Duke Nukem Forever in it's former glory."

reviewText:
The game play is dated.  The must un-fun parts were the monster truck parts maily due to the boring levels and wretched physics.  Some of the truck jumps took multiple tries to complete due to this.  This game plays like it was trying to emulate the gameplay of Half-Life 2, which is a game from 2004.  The gun play feels.... 'off.'  This game seems to be too heavily consolized to enjoy on PC.  There is something strange about the perspective and viewpoint that is hard to describe.  The head wobble when you sprint is nauseating.  Other games seem to pull off head bobbing fine, but this like Duke is taking really high, short steps.
The graphics are also puke.  It looks like a very early Xbox 360 game with low res textures and polygons and recycled objects that make the levels seem barren (even for a desert) and uninspired.
The game is also short, but somehow it just seemed to draaaag on and on.

The only way to recommend this game is if you want to see how bad this game really is and it's on sale for under $5, or if you are some teenie-bopper noob.

Long-time Duke Nukem fans should definitely stay away, as this game will prove how this game should have never been released.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever is a 2011 first-person shooter video game for Microsoft Windows, OS X, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 developed by 3D Realms and Triptych Games and finished by Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is a sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series.
Intended to be groundbreaking, Duke Nukem Forever became a notable example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; the game was released in 2011 after fifteen years of development.
Plot
Twelve years after the events of Duke Nukem 3D. Duke is a worldwide icon, and has achieved great fame from his heroic deeds. After sampling a video game based on his past heroics, he arrives on the set of a talk show for an interview. On his way to the show, Duke witnesses a news broadcast announcing that aliens have once again invaded. Unlike previous encounters, the aliens initially appear peaceful and at first seem to pose no harm to the humans of Earth. Duke's talk show appearance is cancelled to allow television stations to cover the alien invasion, and he retires to the Duke Cave".

reviewText:
I have played many games this year, some good, some bad, but it wasn't until recently that I decided to forget about the reviews and play Duke Nukem Forever for the PC and after I played it I came to a rather disturbing realization, DNF is by far one of the best FPS games I have ever played! No offense to anyone, but I personally think that games like Halo and Call of Duty can NEVER live up to this degree of awesome!

Unlike most FPS games of today, DNF strives to be original and interesting. There was never a moment where I was bored or uninterested, the game was action packed, hilarious, and all around entertaining from beginning to end. It was even more fun than Duke Nukem 3D, and that's really saying something too!

Unlike these so called critics" who complain about everything

reviewText:
Duke Nukem! We have been waiting Forever for this sequel. Just to give you some idea, here is a list of everything that happened while we waited for this game[duke.a-13.net]. This game had so much hype that we were bound to be let down. After all, this is Duke, the 1995 action hero and parody of the action heroes of that era.

What we got was disappointment, and a feeling of Did Not Finish. And, quite frankly, I found the first half of the game to be offensive. While we got hints of sexual innuendo from Duke Nukem 3D where a stripper would flash her breasts, in this game, we have stuff that would be considered sexual harassment in the real world. And, thus, the Duke looks crass instead of having class. I want to blow stuff up and shoot aliens, not slap alien breasts on walls.

As a result of this game, I fear that we have seen Duke's swan song. It was fun while it lasted.

reviewText:
First if you want to see something hilarious, go online and look up PC Gamers review of this game. It is pretty funny. They gave it a 80/100 which is a huge joke. If anything, because of that mistake, their editorial license should be permanently revoked.

Buy this for $5 or less in a sale or not at all. I'm giving it a thumbs up only because the combat is satisfying enough to be enjoyed for one playthrough. As far as the game sucking goes, people are not wrong. It has good sound, the enemies are cool, and the weapons are all decent. One of the biggest problems in the game is level design is lazy and just sucks. It is not a great game because it just feels like generic crap compared to other much better fps games. The graphics are not good at all and there are sections where your fps will drop randomly from 60 to 50 for no reason at all other than bad coding. But it doesn't happen often so the game runs smoothly for the most part. It is a run of the mill decent time if you get it for $5 or less like I did because that is about all this game is worth.

Without yet going into what everyone already knows, I can say that the gameplay could have been done much better, more specifically the level design and interaction in the game. The level design is amatuer at best and feels forced, like they were on a time constraint (which they were). The levels are bland and boring at best. Interacting with something usually consists of pressing E to start opening a door then tapping spacebar repeatedly a few times to pry it open. This mechanic has always been pointless in games and does not need to exist anymore because slamming a key on a keyboard is not considered actual gameplay, so stop using it. Pressing E once is all it should take. Other kinds of interaction include being able to pee in toilets, look in the mirrors to trigger one-liners from Duke, and some other things, all feel pretty pointless and extremely juvenile. Not that the original Duke 3d was sophisticated or anything, it just seems like they took extra pains with this game to make it embarassingly juvenile and goofy. You can also be shrunken down and have to navigate a section of a level while tiny, figuring out what to do, or even drive a RC car at one point while shrunken early on, and none of the gameplay while being shrunken is very well done or very fun at all. One thing that helped ruin the game was its self-awareness. It starts up with Duke playing his own video game then the camera pans back to show two hookers raising up as if they had been sucking him off and they say that the game looked like fun or whatever and Duke quips after 12 ♥♥♥♥ing years it better be". Oh the irony. If Duke could have seen this game he would have kept his face shut. The game constantly refers to the original Duke Nukem 3d and all that does is make us wish we were playing it instead of this mediocre game. Duke also says quotes throughout the game taken directly from several cool movies
date: but it is not funny and is just awkward. The timing is really bad and it just feels juvenile and does not fit the situation. I could just see the writers for this game sitting and snickering like two 7th graders in class talking about boobs and weiners and laughing. Unlike Duke Nukem 3D
recommended: nothing he ever says in this game is funny or feels like it even should have been said at all.\n\nThe main reason this game failed is that if it were another title rather than using the Duke Nukem name
hoursPlayed: it would be a solid lesser known game
voteText: probably even a cult hit like the game Bulletstorm was. Well
helpfulPercent: probably not. Like I said this game is just average at best. But the fact that they slapped the Duke Nukem name on a only average game was a slap in the face because the original Duke 3d was so awesome. Doom was the reason I got into PC gaming back around 1996 and then I discovered Duke Nukem 3d and was instantly blown away and it left a lasting impression on me that I will never forget. Then they released this ♥♥♥♥ and I was mortified.\n\nIt is certainly not worth the $20 price tag it normally has but if you can catch it on sale for $5 like I did and just forget about it being anywhere near as good as Duke Nukem 3d

reviewText:
After rewriting this review for the 1000th and last time, I finally give to you: Duke Nukem Forever!
(With a dash of humor)

Holy Mother Teresa ♥♥♥♥ing a rhino for goat milk, what the hell happened in that 12 year development time!?! (This is the campaign I'm talking about) Who the hell said it would be a good idea for dumb ♥♥♥ turret sections and monster truck rally to be in Duke Forever??

Honestly, I want to defend this game because I'm a die hard fan of Duke Nukem, but I just can't give DNF the love it deserves. (Do make note of my time played on this game) Duke Forever's campaign simply goes like this: Duke get's ♥♥♥♥ sucked, aliens come down for coffee/scones, Duke ready to kill, Duke has no jetpack/must use elevator, aliens go pew pew pew, Duke go pew pew pew, Duke smacks ♥♥♥♥ on wall, Duke smacks ♥♥♥♥ on girl, Duke shoot turret, Duke drive truck, Duke punch big alien in ♥♥♥♥, Duke bungie jump off Hoover Dam, Duke do moar pew pew pew, Cycloid gets deaded. Duke (SPOILER) deaded by Nuke #Irony....... What the ♥♥♥♥....

Duke Nukem Forever was a great concept back in the late 90s/early 2000s, sticking to the Duke 3D routes and keeping it as close to the original while adding new elements of gameplay into the mix that, by the trailers, seems to work out well for it. You got to keep all of your weapons, there was a health and armor system, levels weren't linear, and there was a ♥♥♥♥ING MOTORCYCLE!!! I don't mind a monster truck, but a motorcycle? That's the badass's main ride right there! You don't see a Hell's Angel member in a Honda Civic, just like Duke should be on a Harley rather than a truck. But anyway, Duke Nukem Forever 1998-2004 seemed to stick to it's original roots and not add all of that unneeded Halo garbage that it has now! The Duke Nukem Forever of 2011 was such a Halo and Call of Duty knock off, you could of slapped Call of Nukem: Halo Battlefield" on there and the gameplay would still match the title! What the hell happened to Duke being able to carry 10+ weapons at a time and having to constantly save the game because you don't want to die and restart the episode

-Duke Nukem Forever Review by Angry Joe.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y5Yngipvz6M&feature=feedu
For all those kiddies who barely hit puberty and really don't have any clue what Duke Nukem REALLY is, this is for you. (And also for those who just want to know what DNF is really like)

First off: Duke Nukem Forever HAS BEEN IN DEVELOPMENT for 12 years, but that does not mean Gearbox has been developing it for 12 years. Got that? Good, let's go.

1. For the Graphics Players:
The game is not Crysis. It's not Far Cry 2. It's not even CoD. So, if this is what you base a game on, then don't even bother. DNF is more Serious Sam HD meets HL2 in my opinion. Some textures look awesome, some look really old. Overall, IMO, it's acceptable. I like eye-candy, make no mistake, but this is not what DNF is about. It never was, nor will it ever be.

2. The Profanity, Toilet Humour:
Duke is a dirty SOB. It's been like that ever since he first got voice. It will always be like that. It's part of the Duke Nukem thing". It's even rated for it. Expect cursing
date:
expect spending 20 minutes throwing poop around and jarateing on ♥♥♥♥. It's how it is. Get over it.

3. Gameplay:
This is where I have a serious issue with the game. So

reviewText:
I had a decent time with it, the jokes are funny and very duke like and the game feels just like all the others.

My big complain is the level design, it very much has a Half-Life 2 level structure (Fun for the masses, miserable for the smart), every level consists of fighting a couple enemies, solving a silly jump puzzle or some kind of awkward trick like stacking barrels into a cargo-crate to make it lean another way, then a loading screen. Thanks goodness the game wasn't very long so I could actually bare finishing it.

The multiplayer is very fast paced and rocket based, just like the old duke multiplayers, though I don't know how popular the multiplayer is outside of a few close friends.

If you really love duke to the point his one-liners can carry you through a game, pick it up, if not...well...don't!

reviewText:
All the bad and none of the good of an old school shooter.

Old school shooter positives:
Excellent level design with fun to explore secrets
Carry as many weapons as there are in the game at once
Fast paced action
Well designed puzzels

Old scgool shooter negatives:
Circle strafe boss fights
Back tracking
First person platforming
Terrible Humor
Badly designed puzzels

Duke nukem forever has all of the latter and none of the former.

reviewText: Not as good as Duke Nukem 3D, but this game is certainly not as terrible as a lot of people make out. Yes, the game engine feels dated, yes there's bugs, and yes some of the gameplay is a little repetative. But overall this game is fun to play, Duke is still Duke and it's good to have him back in another game!\n\nI don't think the amount of hype the game had, which was kinda unavoidable after the long development and it's troubles, helped with the game getting slated as much as it did.  Get it when it's on sale if you're a fan of Duke and you're not sure about trying this.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever is a average/below average game.

It managed to be completely average throughout the entire gameplay.The guns do not feel good,the only decent weapon is the shotgun,the rest are just boring.The puzzles are bad and done in a fashion that will either irritate you or annoy you.The enemies are also boring.The only thing that stands out are the boss battles which are OK.The limited arsenal just adds up to the boring theme of the game.

I feel like the game would be worth to play just for the Duke Nukem quotes.

The game is packed with boring levels and sections and even the turret sections are bad or boring.There are some parts of the game that will ignite you but as I said before,those are most likely the boss fights.

The game is not bad, but it's averageness makes me not recommend it.

reviewText: You should play it because it's Duke Nukem, it's fun, but somehow it seems like it didn't age that well.\nThe jokes, references and one-liners are really good, but that doesn't take 9 years to make. The game suffered from too much hype around it, which made some people think it was going to be really good, add that to the stale gameplay and crappy graphic options and it seems too outdated for a modern game.\nAs a game it's a below average B-style FPS with not much to play with apart from the original's humor and un-seriousness, and you can have fun with that

reviewText:
Duke Nukem: Forever is the sequel to Duke Nukem 3D, a classic game from the 1990's that inspired hundreds of games, mostly due to it's entertaining gameplay, well designed levels, and humour. Duke Nukem: Forever had big shoes to fill, and while it doesn't live up to the hype surrounding its release, it's definitely an enjoyable game despite the flaws.
This game has you once again playing as the Duke, living life as a celebrity after crushing the alien invasion in the previous game. The intro of the game has you reliving an awesome fight from the previous game before navigating your house and heading to an interview. While you'll notice the dodgy animations and skewed voicework, you'll also notice the astonishing amount of interactivity and abundance of items in the environment. Numerous posters and various memorabilia concerning Duke Nukem is scattered around the levels, and displays an enormous amount of fan service. You can interact with a large number of items in the environment, including pool tables, telephones, DVD players, toilets, vibrators (?), food, arcade games, weights, basketball, frisbees and even an actual turd (?). This lends itself to the novelty and humour of the game and was definitely one of the standards.
While the actual combat in the game isn't awful, it does feel clunky and dated by today's standards. Many of the weapons lack punch, and end up feeling as if you're firing a glorified water gun. The only satisfying gun in the game is the shotgun, which is relatively to find and locate ammunition for. The rest of the guns are clumsy and spongy to use on enemies.
Unfortunately, the level design is also quite linear. There's little exploration to be had, and it's relatively easy to find objects like ammo pickups. The constrictive and repetitive level design gets repetitive pretty quickly, and the blandly grey environments don't help this very much.
The boss fights in this game are surprisingly solid, and reminded me of old school games like Doom 3. These fights are entertaining and bombastic, but frustrating in that you can only damage them with a single weapon type. This limits the players style and actively forces you to play the game in a specific way. The game's real problem is the lack of creativity and restrictive mechanics, which contradicts the content found in Duke Nukem 3d.
The best way to experience Duke Nukem: Forever is the same as a popcorn action movie; turn your brain off, play it once, and don't look too carefully into it. The fun moments in this game make up for the bad ones, and the nostalgic value of this game probably elevated my score slightly. 7 / 10

reviewText:
Ah nostalgia.  I was a sophmore in College when the amazing Duke Nukem 3D came out and intorduced the craziness that is Duke.  That was an amazing game if you have never played it, be it a bit old now and graphics are rough but still great gameplay unfolds.

Over a decade and half later we finally get DNF.  Being the Duke fan I am it is hard for me to criticize this game and the series.  DNF is the foundation of utter chaos from a game developing stand point.  I think Gearbox did OK with its release and the other developers put out a fun game here.  Based on publcation reviews it would appear to be the next Superman 64... but I would not go that far.

This game has issues and problems for sure, like dated graphics, a forgettable soundtrack and humor that may be outdatted.  That said, its still Duke, raunchy, vulgar, immature and at times very fun.  This is a game to play at your liesure and not get to serious, just blow crap up and shoot aliens.  I could do with out the physics puzzles and jumping games, I do wish it was just more in your face FPS.

I would be upset if I shelled out $60 for this game as I don't think its worth that, but if on sale, its a good buy and will give plenty of gametime.  Hail Duke, the King is back (sorta).

✓Recommended

reviewText:
Pure Puken = The epitome of FPS stupidity.

This is not the 90's anymore kiddies, I mean developers.

You wanna know why Duke and Doom were so popular back then? Because there were no other shooters. So playing the first ever 3d shooter while constantly sprinting and blasting at warhogs while carrying tons of weapons as well as having an occasional laugh at what the Duke or his enemies were doing was a blast.

But on the other hand, how do you make an FPS interesting wherein you simply mow down rows of enemies? I don't know, Serious Sam did it and that game had co-op. Bulletstorm did it. To tell you the truth, when I was watching the gameplay trailers I was trying not to think: what? that's IT?" because for some reason I was believing that there was something more to the gameplay and the game itself that was being kept secret

reviewText:
The game that taught hundreds of thousands of people worldwide a valuable lesson in preordering video games; don't.

Duke Nukem Forever is a shadow of its predecessors (and nearly every other FPS on Steam), with uninspired level design, unsatisfying guns (of which you can only carry two of at a time), and a slow-trodding pace that seems inhumanly cruel to pair with a fast-paced series like Duke Nukem.

Duke Nukem 3D: Megaton Edition is worth your money, get that instead and save yourself some money (and regret).

reviewText:
I feel a bit like Duke on this one, me against the world. I actually found this game to be very entertaining, and here are the reasons why.

First of all, it's Duke! That should be enough for you right there. But in all seriousness this game is not as bad as people claim. It all depends on what you are willing to accept to play as your favorite over the top macho man again. It is an oldskool shooter that will remind us that was gaming in the 90's of a simpler time. When you dident need a gripping story about how everything was terrible and serious, you just wanted to have some fun!

And fun it is, from the very start where you can walk around your palace like appartment and interact with the environment to the over the top action scenes with monsters big as houses eating your RPG one rocket at a time. The nudiebar is one of my favorite places since it gives you a break from the normal gameplay and lets you interact with stuff in the world. Beeing able to flush a toilet or use a pool table is such a throwback to the good old games before Call of Battle: Russia must die!

But ofcourse there are faults with the game. You can notice that there have been lots and lots of different people working on this over a long period of time. The vechicle parts of the game are terrible and the turret sections makes me want to point the gun at myself instead. But it's not worse than say the CoD single player campaigns or the Battlefield ones.

If you can relax and just take this game for what it is you will have a good time with it. But if you have problem with slapstick humor, full frontal nudity and double-entendres, this is not (and has never been) a game for you.

reviewText:
''It's time to chew ♥♥♥'' - ♥♥♥♥ Kickem
It follows classic Duke Nukem gameplay, but adds useless side animations (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, Eating, Making popcorn, Drawing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on chalkboards, playing SlotMachines,) which gives you EGO boosts.

But when it comes to combat, they tried too hard to give it a Triple A game feel to it.
But I, unlike others, appreciate their effort.

In short, if you really really enjoyed Duke Nukem 3D as a child, and forgot such things as Stories from all the old games, this Duke game's illogical story (''♥♥♥♥ America's safety, where are they taking our babes?'') will just let you go into the gun-happy frenzy you were supposed to do.

Threw poop at an enemy 10/10

reviewText:
I could make this review a whole joke but I think I'll actually make a serious post about this.

This game actually wasn't that bad.
Oh yeah, it has some MAJOR flaws but I still had fun with it.
Stuff like only carrying 2 or 4 weapons, glitchy grayfics, and some boring sections with not much going on are some of my major problems with this.
But despite all this I had some fun with it

The main campaign is overall, mediocre
The DLC campaign tho, is actually surprisingly better, not great but still better than the rest of the game.

Just don't go in expecting that much and you might enjoy it a bit, or maybe you won't.
(If you end up buying this when its on sale or something be sure to get the doctor who cloned me dlc)

(Ignore the multiplayer dlc, I never saw more than 6 people playing online so save that money)

reviewText:
Screw the haters. Understand what kind of game this is, and you'll enjoy it.

Allow me to elaborate: This game is not the pinnacle of game design, or full of fresh ideas, or show-stopping in any way. What it is is a fun shooter with plenty of throwbacks and references to the 90's/early 2000's. It's not without its flaws, but it is plenty of fun and worthy of a collection, especially for a tenner.

Graphics- No, they aren't great. No, they don't push the limits of anything beyond a low-midrange computer. But they get the job done and do look good while doing so. Pigcops, certain cars, certain weapons, octabrains, and bosses are modeled very well, and you can definitely tell what they are and what they were modeled after (meaning you'll recognize a battlelord right away if you've played Duke3D). Plus, since this game doesn't push high-end setups, it's accessible to everyone.

Sound- Not much to speak of here. The sound is done well. Guns have enough punch. Music is done well. Stereo separation and directional audio does what it needs to.

Gameplay- Honestly, this is where it matters most. You do buy a game for gameplay, not to just look at graphics. Again, don't expect this to rule the gaming world with fresh, innovative play. But, if you're looking for a shooter that's fast, precise, and doesn't do much of the cover mechanic, this is it. Plenty of stuff to shoot, plenty of guns to use, plenty of bosses to fight and die against.

Overall, good for several playthroughs and some multiplayer. This is a basic 2011 shooter with 1998 roots, and they show. I happen to like gameplay like this. If you also do, buy and enjoy. If not, go ahead and move on.

reviewText: Despite the worst reviews possible, i honestly dont think its that bad. Infact i really enjoy DNF even though i havent finished it all quite yet. I never played the original duke nukem's so i have nothing to compare them to, but i have loved this version. The reviews complaimed about graphics, linear gameplay, and innapropriateness, but thoser factors are not what i look for in this kind of game. I bought this game to have fun, not for a serious hardcore experience. So wether if the gameplay is liear, of if the graphics are a bit dated, it doesnt effect the fun experience. As for graphics, i cant say anything abotu the consoles, but personally for 13 years of development, with multiple restarts on the graphics, they look pretty damn good maxed out. As for the innapropriateness, i thought that was the point of this game? People said duke took it to far thsi time buti guess thats just personal oppinon.\n\nAll in all i am glad i bought DNF, and have had a blast with it, with more to come.

reviewText: Great game if you are a retro gamer or were ever a fan of the series. It is what it is, a Duke Nukem game, if you were expecting deep storyline or coverbased tactical combat you won't find it here, it plays like a classic arcade FPS and I love it for that. The graphics are pretty good in my opinion, considering the ancient engine its running on, I would have preferred to see it on something better in terms of game engine, but I'm content with what it is. I paid full price for this game, and I have no regrets, it is exactly what it promised to be, a Duke Nukem Game. I should note however I'm a Duke Nukem fan since his 2D platformer days so I'm a bit   biased on this one, still if you love retro FPS games or arcade shooters , this may be the game for you.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever (DNF) got bad reviews overall, but do yourself a favour and mostly ignore them. Have in mind most reviews are biased, and this is suppose to be an old school FPS, with a lenghty campaign (it will take you between 10 and 15 hours to complete if you are an experienced player) and a very fun MP with a lot of customizable options. Have in mind this game was intended for release in 1999, a time when FPS's were simplistic and it was all about firepower and testosterone driven characters, and Duke delivers on both ends. As a direct sequel to Duke Nukem 3D, DNF delivers the same amount of insanity, action and adrenaline as it's predecessor. Compared to todays shooters, it is a dinosaur of a game, outdated in structure and gameplay mechanics, but it still is a lot of fun, and a great throwback to the 90's, a decade that revolutionized video games.

This is how old school games are suppose to be, and if you like crude humour, naked chicks and epic one liners, this game is for you. It took 15 years for this game to see the light of day, so when you buy this, you are getting a piece of video game history. The worlds most famous vaporware is ready to be played. It took forever (no pun intended), but it's here.

Always bet on Duke.

The Good

-Old school badassery in spades
-Easter egg galore
-Fun shooting mechanics
-Epic one liners
-Lenghty campaign
-Awesome firepower

The Bad

-Too simplistic when compared to more modern shooters
-Difficulty level can be a problem to some players (Personally I love a good challenge)
-Style of this game appeals mostly to hardcore gamers

6.5/10

reviewText: I remember playing Duke Nukem in it's various forms while growing up.  When I heard this was coming out, I had such high hopes.  And they were dashed.  Violently.  I tried to like it, I really did.  But apparently I've matured enough that the low-brow humor isn't quite as funny anymore (misogynist, anyone?).  The graphics are OK, but the controls suck (I'm a mouse and keyboard kind of guy).  Finally I just gave up; I couldn't finish it.  As neat as it was to see an old PC memory come back with modern graphics, it wasn't worth it.  Even on sale I doubt I'd buy it.  Let that be your warning.

reviewText:
The game that taught hundreds of thousands of people worldwide a valuable lesson in preordering video games; don't.

Duke Nukem Forever is a shadow of its predecessors (and nearly every other FPS on Steam), with uninspired level design, unsatisfying guns (of which you can only carry two of at a time), and a slow-trodding pace that seems inhumanly cruel to pair with a fast-paced series like Duke Nukem.

Duke Nukem 3D: Megaton Edition is worth your money, get that instead and save yourself some money (and regret).

reviewText:
Male chauvinists COME ON DOWN! Duke Nukem has given me some obnoxiously fun gaming that I haven't had in quite some time (except maybe insurance fraud in Saints Row 2). I was laughing throughout the entire campaign. It's a non-stop parody of greatness. It's hard to describe how many games and movies were spoofed on, but the obvious one is Half-Life 2. There's pieces of Alien and Matrix, plus Schwarzenegger movies. The one-liners are delivered to perfection--creative, witty, and absolutely vulgar in every way.

This game must have annoyed the hell out of the early reviewers because a 30 metascore out of the gate is just unwarranted. Now it's up to 54...better, but give me a break. No where near as bad as those ♥♥♥♥♥♥s make it out to be. Seriously, this game must have been reviewed by feminists, homosexuals, or just plain ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that can't handle some ♥♥♥♥♥ in their face. And yes--lots of boobie action to be had here.

An epic knockout. Duke Nukem Forever delivers. Highly enjoyable.

reviewText:
I feel a bit like Duke on this one, me against the world. I actually found this game to be very entertaining, and here are the reasons why.

First of all, it's Duke! That should be enough for you right there. But in all seriousness this game is not as bad as people claim. It all depends on what you are willing to accept to play as your favorite over the top macho man again. It is an oldskool shooter that will remind us that was gaming in the 90's of a simpler time. When you dident need a gripping story about how everything was terrible and serious, you just wanted to have some fun!

And fun it is, from the very start where you can walk around your palace like appartment and interact with the environment to the over the top action scenes with monsters big as houses eating your RPG one rocket at a time. The nudiebar is one of my favorite places since it gives you a break from the normal gameplay and lets you interact with stuff in the world. Beeing able to flush a toilet or use a pool table is such a throwback to the good old games before Call of Battle: Russia must die!

But ofcourse there are faults with the game. You can notice that there have been lots and lots of different people working on this over a long period of time. The vechicle parts of the game are terrible and the turret sections makes me want to point the gun at myself instead. But it's not worse than say the CoD single player campaigns or the Battlefield ones.

If you can relax and just take this game for what it is you will have a good time with it. But if you have problem with slapstick humor, full frontal nudity and double-entendres, this is not (and has never been) a game for you.

reviewText:
NOTE: This Is an update for the review, much more detail of the game and such. Pointing out the good and bad of the game.

Ahh, we've been waiting forever for Duke Nukem Forever. An game that's been In developement hell for 12 years. And the squeal to Duke Nukem 3D, and DNF basically Ignored the past Duke spin-offs like Zero Hour, Land of the Babes, and Time to Kill. Since THIS IS, a squeal to Duke3D.

Now, this game Is known for being an pretty bad game, reviewers mostly point out the flaws Instead of the good. There Is some good, there Is some bad. The Good, Is Duke himself, he hasn't changed much, not one bit. The Babes are back (they do look souless xD), the weapons from Duke3D return once again, and the combat Is pretty good. The Bad, Is the wall boobs (yes, there Is wall boobs, you can slap them), the jokes aren't as clever anymore, they're more Immature once and a while. The regenerating health, and two weapon thing (there Is an option to expand the Inventory). They tried mixing classic FPS and modern FPS, the two. Really don't go together, but DNF kind of done It right. The game was pretty fun, It's kind of addicting also. Specially the Muiltplayer. But, there IS some hackers In the Muiltplayer. Which kind of makes It, not so fun at times. So, I'd suggest getting out of a game If you spot an hacker.

Well, the story feels more like a rehash or retelling of Duke3D, Ailens have returned to Earth once again to capture the women, and Duke yet again has to save the world. Simple story for simple fun! The levels are an bit linear at this time, but they're fine.

The game also has an DLC which gives you another campiang called The Doctor Who Cloned Me. (I haven't tried this out yet).
And some Muiltplayer DLC which adds more maps.

Would I recommend DNF? Well, sure It has some flaws and It's hated on deeply. But Hey, It's better than Postal 3, which Is an game RWS doesn't want you to even buy! DNF has some good In there, and It's totally recommended. A good 7/10 In my book!

reviewText:
I could make this review a whole joke but I think I'll actually make a serious post about this.

This game actually wasn't that bad.
Oh yeah, it has some MAJOR flaws but I still had fun with it.
Stuff like only carrying 2 or 4 weapons, glitchy grayfics, and some boring sections with not much going on are some of my major problems with this.
But despite all this I had some fun with it

The main campaign is overall, mediocre
The DLC campaign tho, is actually surprisingly better, not great but still better than the rest of the game.

Just don't go in expecting that much and you might enjoy it a bit, or maybe you won't.
(If you end up buying this when its on sale or something be sure to get the doctor who cloned me dlc)

(Ignore the multiplayer dlc, I never saw more than 6 people playing online so save that money)

reviewText:
To everyone who was disappointed by this game, my question to you is: what were you expecting?

Admitted, my experiences with Duke Nukem only go as far as the N64 games, so I may not have the same nostalgia as some fans, but from the perspective of someone looking for a fun video game, this is a fun video game.

It's a first person shooter, as the later Duke games were, and as far as shooting action, it's pretty average. I played through for the first time on hard difficulty, and aside from frustration with a few of the bosses, it wasn't overly challenging. The weapon and enemy variation is small, but it does the job.

Where this game shines is all of the extra stuff available in the game. Interacting with the world is actively encouraged as it raises your max health, but there's plenty of stuff that offers no game benefit yet really adds to the atmosphere. I probably spent a good hour just reading all the labels in the Duke Burger level. There's 9-ball, air hockey, pinball and more stuff that you don't need to even look at to finish the game, but would be missed if not included. The humor of this game is crude (as you would expect), but it's still fun to experience.

If you're looking for an innovative first-person shooter, this isn't your game. If you're the type of gamer that enjoys exploring every nook and cranny of a level for secrets, then you'll have a good experience. If you enjoy boobs, ballshots and other crude humor then this is your Game of the Year.

reviewText:
I enjoyed the older versions bought through Steam. I am also enjoying this game. I believe the metacritic score, along with most of those reviews of which it is comprised, is misleading. Better to read the Steam user reviews in this case. I would certianly score it somewhere in the 70-80 range for a FPS. Obviously, I would try to procure this game on sale certainly as it has been out for quite some time.

Based on the low critic score, I had low expectations. But as I play the game, I am pleasantly surprised and am finding it addicitng. Even though, as I play, I find myself forgetting what my objectives are, the flow of the game is good, the graphics are good-enough, it is broken up into nicely timed auto saves, there always seems to be something new and different with each level, different scenarios allow for the applications of different weapons, and fighting the Bosses is fun.

This is the first review I wrote, mainly because as I am about 30-40% done and I think it is a good game from a good series that seems to have gotten misleadingly smeared a bit by the metacritic community.

The DLC Doctor Who Cloned Me is better. I am really enjoying playing it. Dylan is a great sidekick. The visit to the Burning Bush is refreshing. Good game and good game character.

reviewText:
Despite the negative reviews, Duke Nukem Forever is actually quite a good game in its own right, as long as it isn't viewed comparatively to its predecessor Duke Nukem 3D.

The game's single player component is a linear shooter campaign reminiscent of the Halo series which featured regenerating health & a 2 weapon carry system. The latter didn't work too well in DNF due to the power structure of the game's weapon set, though upping the carriable weapons to 4 in the game's option menu resolves any issues. The game featured lots of variety throwing in driving, platforming, turret & minigame sections, which were actually excelently placed, alternating nicely with the standard first person shooting gameplay sections so you never had too much of one thing at a time. Wolfenstein: The New Order notably had a problem with doing just that as the game threw non-combat after non-combat section at you in the middle portion of the game in a maybe 4:1 ratio with the first person shooting & bundled up all of the game's fps at the beginning & ends, so kudos to 3D Realms/Gearbox for getting that right.

Forever's FPS component is actually a lot of fun despite the regen health, limited weapon capacity & the slow movement speed. Shooting aliens is still shooting aliens, & DNF does it well.

Story wise, it's whacky & expected. Basically the aliens from 3D come back to earth, attack & abduct all the women, & you, being Duke Nukem have to defeat them & save everyone. The writing frequently makes nostalgic references to not only DN3D but also other games from the time period like Doom & System Shock 2. The one liners are also enjoyable in the game, as always. One particular segment I liked was where Duke, shrunk to the size of an action figure navigates across a pantry shooting shrunk aliens.

The multiplayer is reminiscent of arena shooters. Despite having a 2 weapon limit in a set clearly not designed for such a thing, it also works quite well, the teamplay mode in particular can feature some cooperation between players using different weapons to their advantages.

Overall, DNF isn't a work of art, no one really expected it to be, & it doesn't live up to 12 years of hype, or the awesome 2001 trailer, or its predecessor Duke Nukem 3D, but if you were to use one word to describe it, it would be fun. DNF is just that, a whole lot of whacky fun to be enjoyed for the right price. I payed $7.50 & don't regret it.

6/10

reviewText:
Duke Nukem: Forever has recieved many mixed opinions throughout its time with new players and those already acquainted with the Duke Nukem franchise. I myself was an avid fan of Duke Nukem 3D on the N64, and played it regularly with my brother anf friends for a long period of time. So, being familiar with Duke Nukem myself, I can say that my review will be based a little on my appreciation for Duke Nukem franchise, however I will try to be as unbiased as possible.

Duke Nukem, having previously saved the world from the alien invasion, is now regarded as a celebrity and world superstar amongst the global population. The aliens once again attack the earth and steal the babes (only the hot ones) in search of revenge against their nemesis and planet earth. As a result, Duke Nukem goes back into action to save the world from the aliens once again.

With a really nice graphical update from its predecessor (this game has been in development for a very long time), as well as Duke's classic inappropriate wit, I definitely enjoyed reliving the Duke Nukem experience. Some may say it goes a little over the top, however Duke's personality as well as those of other character such as Captain Dylan, make this a very comical FPS experience, with plenty of cheesy lines and film references to boot. Although a simple storyline (very typically Duke Nukem style), the FPS experience is still enjoyable, with classic weapons such as the shrink ray, expansion ray, trip mines, holo Duke etc. Ego boosts such as lifting weights, or shooting hoops can increase your ego (which acts as a health bar) as you progress through the campaign. As well as ego boosts, there are also other hidden Easter Eggs to find, making the levels fun to explore. A game worth getting for any Duke Nukem fan in my opinion, especially during the sales, and also worth playing for those new to the franchise.

Pros
+ The full Duke Nukem experience with bucket loads of comical quotes and references
+ Classic enemies and weapons
+ Hidded Easter Eggs (Ego boosts + more)
+ DLC for an extended storyline, which is also great fun for those who love the base game (cheap on sale)
+ Achievements

Cons
- Fairly standard FPS mechanics
- Some frustrating and tedious section (such as using a turret against incoming ships)
- The occasional bug can make AI enemies and companions become stuck
- When pig cops jump at you they kind of float in mid-air towards you rather that having a fluid jump

My Score: 7/10
voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a fan of the Duke Nukem series and played all of them (not steam versions) still worth getting.
Duke Nukem Forever has had some bad reports, but to be honest I actually found this game fun and entertaining. True the story is a bit bland but the constant shooting and some puzzle solving areas made up for it. Kept in mind I have only completed this game in Single Player Easy mode.
Personal note: Love the music tracks in this game.

Single Player
Well story mode is plainly simple, aliens come down and tries to take over. President orders Duke to not get involved but Duke of course will and goes shooting all their asses back to where they came from. (Dont want to give to much away with the extras you will have to find out yourself.)

Multiplayer
Found 3 servers from my location in Australia and they are dead. So I cant give an opinion on that.

Issues
Only 1 problem I had found with this game is the graphics had to be lowered during the Monster Truck ghost town section where you have to jump over the valleys. Reason is because the physics engine in the game doesnt like modern machines and wont allow the vehicle to jump over with enough speed. (Got fustrated till I had to search a walkthrough and this is how I found out the problem.)

Personal Rating 7.5/10

reviewText: Always bet on Duke. Remove the hype, the 12-14 years of development or any sort of information regarding Gearbox and play Duke Nukem Forever only as a fan. Opinions may be polarised on DNF, but it is much like the original in it's brash mature rated content, crude sense of humour and snappy pop-culture references. The game itself is a fairly solid shooter featuring an often unreported level of interactivity in the levels, with focus on branched out set-pieces and secrets. Triptych Games, and 3D Realms before them, pumped alot of heart in Duke Nukem Forever and their work is respectable to the Duke Nukem franchise as such. If you're expecting anything visually on par with the recent HD generation titles, this is the wrong place to look. Duke Nukem Forever also lacks a competant multiplayer. Both of these are minor issues however. Besides some niggling design choices otherwise, including the ability to only cary two weapons, I'd respond only with this - come get some""

reviewText:
I tried to play this game, I really did but it really hurt playing.

It bored me so much and there was a lot of hype around the game while in developement but when we finally got it, it was just BAD.  Like REALLY bad!

I am lucky I did not pay full price for the game, after playing original Duke and loving them, I thought this would be no different but from the very quick gameplay that was painful to play.. I knew it was not.

The graphics are bland, the audio is repeated and the controls are simple.  Nothing more to say on that.

I played 0.8 hours and I could not play anymore.  When the campaign bored me after a few mins I tried the online... 2 matches and then the game was uninstalled.  Really bad boring no fun game I found.

It just does not offer anything new to the game of Duke.  Constant repeated sounds and updated graphics from original.  Otherwise it is the same, LITERALLY.

reviewText:
I was a big fan of Duke Nukem 3D. I remember those weekends listening to Don Henley's greatest hits, playing that game, and messing around with the build editor (my first and only experience designing FPS maps) quite fondly. At the time the next Duke Nukem game was a huge freaking deal to me. After a few years I lost my patience and moved on, like any normal person. Fast forward another decade or so and finally Duke Nukem Forever arrives, and it's garbage. No wait, that's just what they say right? I'm more than capable of playing games and formulating opinions on them, so who cares what they say.

So I played through it....
....oops?
Duke Nukem Forever is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥. I hate using bad language in reviews but DNF deserves all of it and more.

The original Duke Nukem 3D has a linear format, you go from one stage to the next. However those stages are large, varied, and include numerous optional paths, secret areas, and methods of exploration(jet-pack, steroid-boosted jumps, etc). Duke Nukem Forever is entirely linear. For the most part in DNF you're either shooting a handful of aliens in quasi-arena areas, doing some ridiculous puzzle, partaking in a vehicle-section, or doing some ego-boosting activity. Oh and for the entirety of the game your sensibilities on what makes for quality game-design or at least in-offensive content are dragged through horse manure.

Vehicle sections - All too often FPS developers feel the need to include vehicle-sections. They use the word variety" which is short for "we decided the actual game wasn't compelling". Some developers can rise above
date: and that's because they use vehicles in an intelligent manner. Half-Life 2 is a good example

voteText: and makes for good pacing. The Halo series is also a good example

votesTotal: but let's not put in the effort to make it quality." Vehicle-sections are a constant in DNF

The main point is that DNF has vehicle-sections because they needed to pad the game out somehow.\n\nThe combat/gun-play - When you're making a first-person-shooter the shooter aspects should be compelling. There are several games that get this most basic element right. Duke Nukem Forever...doesn't. For a 1996 game

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever's (DNF) single-player campaign was a lot of fun because of the colorful and interesting environments and Duke's crass, over-the-top, sex humor. I gave it a composite score of 6.375/10 (turn off the Depth of Field graphics option, and I give it a 7.375/10).

If you're interested in playing a funny, old-school shooter, give it a try when it's on sale. Definitely get the Cloned" DLC and skip the multiplayer one.

Expect ~14 hr campaign +4 hrs for DLC

I went into DNF thinking it was a shooter satire or self-parody rather than a serious attempt at a shooter

reviewText: Hail to the King Baby! Finally I finished playing the game after I waited 16 years for the release, bought it right on the release date and playing it for the first only to the point where I could not continue due to an lack of motivation and an increasing frustration. Altough the humor of the game don't have to hide behind it's original, it's seemed to me to be overall less free, less fun and much more difficult  from time to time. Espacially to find you way through the after all one dimensional levels. After a four year pause I reinstalled it and played it to the end. I must say that the graphics isn't realy that bad for a title that released 2012, but especially the finally is dull, weak and leaves you with the impression that they just wanted to finish the game no matter what, so all the work wasn't for nothing. So I got realy mixed up feelings about Duke Forever. Still...it's a part of gaming history...in some way.
