reviewText:
Download size: about 8 GB
Playtime: about 10 hours

Duke Nukem Forever (DNF) was the follow-up to Duke Nukem 3D from over a decade prior, which means nostalgia and high expectations played a large part in how the game was originally reviewed. As Duke says himself near the beginning of the game “after 12 ♥♥♥♥ing years, it better be (good).” Sadly, the game was thoroughly mediocre and nobody was impressed. Strangely, DNF has a 55 metacritic rating which is rare for a big name game but the Steam player reviews for the game are “mostly positive.” I’d guess that’s because no matter how disappointing the game is, it still isn’t “horrible.”

It’s been so long since I played the old DOS game Duke Nukem 3D (Or Duke Nukem 1 & 2 before that) so I can’t really recap it. Fortunately, you don’t need to have played to older games to get what’s going on in DNF. An alien fleet is looming over the Earth and the US president is confident that peace negotiations are going well. It’s a good chance these are the same aliens from the previous Duke Nukem games so the president is worried that our hero Duke is going to pick a fight and start a war. Naturally, the aliens attack (and start stealing Earth’s hot women) so it’s up to Duke Nukem to kick their asses once again.

Gameplay for Duke Nukem Forever is straightforward first person shooter with no real innovations, except a few places in the game where you get shrunk down to the size of a Barbie doll and need to navigate terrain puzzles while avoiding the huge (normal size) aliens. The puzzles in the game are not too difficult to figure out, which is a good thing because DNF doesn’t have a “hint” system (where you hit a button and it shows you where you’re supposed to go next). Usually the door you’re supposed to go through has an orange flash, but it is still possible in a few places not to know what to do next (like one level in particular involving a crane wrecking ball).

When I first played through the game about a year ago, one of the gripes I had was the limited weapon inventory. For a first person shooter there’s actually an adequate variety of guns to choose from, both human and alien (pistol, shotgun, machinegun, rocket launcher, etc.) The problem was that you could only carry 2 weapons at a time like in Halo 1.  When you run out of ammo, you can drop the gun you’re holding and pick one up from a fallen enemy. This would have been fine except that one of the game’s Steam achievements requires you to carry the pistol for the entire game, leaving you with 1 other weapon. I believe the developers patched it though, so now you can carry 4 weapons at any given time. The game’s health system is the now standard regenerating life system except that instead of being called health, it’s called ego. You can raise your maximum ego by doing various environmental things like looking a porno magazines or lifting weights that you find lying around on various levels. Most of your ego boosts will probably come from killing bosses though.

Pros:
+Fights with giant alien bosses are always a plus in my book. Unfortunately, only a couple of these fights involve outside the box thinking. For example the giant alien queen requires pipe bombs and dodging alien impregnators. Most boss fights just require spamming rockets and circle strafing. All bosses can only be hurt by turrets and explosive weapons.
+Decent variety in enemies and environments. The game’s graphics aren’t bad when it comes to the grotesque alien enemies that you’re facing. You get an up close look at a few of the melee enemies. I wasn’t a big fan of the alien hive level because of the weird night vision system that the game uses (Duke Vision) but at least  it changes things up a bit. The underwater level was kind of fun where you need to swim from air supply to air supply.

Cons:
-Outdated humor. The game makers tried to keep the feel of the old Duke Nukem games by having Duke constantly spit out one liners and other macho stuff. The problem is that he seems to say something every time you kill an enemy so some of the quotes keep repeating over and over (“Wonder how many pork chops I can make out of you” after killing a pig alien which is one of the most common enemies in the game). Since you’re killing aliens every few seconds a ton of the quotes are heard about a hundred times by the end of the game. Have you seen the Expendables movies with Sylvester Stallone and Arnold Schwarzenegger? You know how all the old washed up action heroes keep using quotes from their successful movies? The DNF humor feels kind of like that.
-The game just doesn’t stand out in any way. If this wasn’t supposed to be the glorious return of Duke Nukem, the game wouldn’t have been such a disappointment. People would have just said, “meh nothing special about the game. Play it and forget it.” But of course the fans seem to feel like the 12 years since the previous game should have been spent perfecting Duke Nukem Forever.

A friend was using the Steam family sharing thing to play DNF off of my account and I asked why of all the available games he would be playing a game so mediocre. He said it was because he hadn’t tried it but had played the previous Duke Nukem games. I guess it’s like the Aliens vs. Predator movie franchise. Everyone seems to think the movies suck, but I like Aliens and I like Predators, so might as well see the movie once. Make sure that you don’t pay too much for the game though (less than $5). As for the game’s DLC “The Doctor Who Cloned Me,” the DLC is actually pretty long (about 5 hours I think) and doesn’t really add much new to the experience. I think there’re only a couple new weapons, but there are a few new bosses to fight.

reviewText:
Underrated Game
The game might have some flaws, but overall it's pretty much what I expected from Duke Nukem: Over the top, silly and just fun. Not at all a game that deserves a metascore of ~50/100.

The interaction with the game world is great. You can lift weights, play pinball or pool, sign autographs, drink beer, take a leak, etc. Especially the beginning and the strip club level shine in this regard. This interaction with the world makes the game pretty unique. The action is solid and the fights are pretty challenging (I play on hard mode). The only thing that's not fun is the driving: The game is filled with driving sequences and they get a little annoying over the time.

Pros:

- Great interaction with the environment

- Silly Duke Nukem humor

- Solid shootouts

- Simple retro fps: No unfitting skill/experience system (The new Shadow Warrior is doing this unfortunately...)

- Lenghty campaign: Much longer  than your average modern fps

- Cool weapons: Shrinking cannons, freezing cannons, etc. The game keeps the cool weapons from Duke 3d

- Variety of different environments: Casinos, deserts, organic alien environments, etc. The levels don't get boring



Cons:

- Dated graphics: especially outdoors, but the game has its moments (sometimes it actually looks good).

- Almost no blood! This really bugs me. Enemies often explode into meaty pieces, but leave no blood decals. I would expect much more blood from Duke Nukem.

- Unfitting weapon restrictions / regenerating health: Strange modernizations in an otherwise old-school game. It should use health packs and it should let you carry all your weapons at the same time. While initially you were only allowed to carry two weapons, a patch changed that number to four. Still: This shouldn not be restricted at all.

- Tedious driving sequences

- No mod support: Duke Nukem 3D had a great modding community, and it even has today. Not supporting mods for this one is just stupid.

~75/100 would be a fitting score, I would go as far as giving it 80+.

reviewText:
Yeah, I don't have many hours on this, as I don't have many hours on the other 180+ steam games I own. I have too many to play and am too flustered when it comes to picking, so I never play anything, lol. I spend more time trying to decide what I want to play then actually playing anything at all, now on to the review.

I grew up with games like this and I must say that I don't agree with all the negativity that surrounds the game. It's nothing game breaking, nor is it anything revolutionary, but what it does do fairly well is Duke Nukem. If you are expecting Duke Nukem, you will get Duke Nukem, in all his updated graphical glory. If you are expecting to play something that is leaps and bounds beyond its time, look elsewhere.

Bottom line - If you like Duke Nukem you will enjoy this game. If you are not sure, play the classics, love them, then play this and appreciate it for what it is. This truely is a decent sequel for the modern era and I enjoy it. When I get around to finishing the rest of it, I will enjoy that also. There are many other games, MANY that would be a bigger waste of your money than this.

P.S. - Don't listen to the negative 2 and 3 line reviews. Some people just jump on a band-wagon and criticize something because they don't know how to think for them selves. We call those people sheep. If you enjoy classic shooters, you will enjoy this.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem 3D: Suсk it Down Edition
It is going to be remembered forever as a fail of epic proportions:

All levels are extremely tiny, linear, dumb and uninspiring.
Transitions between some of the levels are nonsensical: why is there a need for the desert sequence at all if you could just fly to the Hoover Dam in a helicopter (just like president and his chopper)?
The monster truck sequence deservers separate point: it is *annoying*. The controls of this thing are atrocious, making it impossible to handle, and the whole driving part is so long, spanning well over 3 levels.
Indoor grahpics are quite... fine... but everything outside looks... well, let's just say it's not for the faint-hearted.
There's no jetpack ever. Hello?
Ugly humor.
So much for all the astronomical hype 3D Realms generated for it over the years it was in the making.

If Duke was real, he'd go medieval on their аsses.

reviewText:
Finally finished this a little while ago but only just now decided to write a review because it's hard to talk about this game in a way that doesn't make me seem like a double standard making jackass. Plus the standard negative stuff about DNF has been beaten to death over and over again in a way that would make Duke himself blush. So I'll try not to fall into that trap.

It's hard to talk about Duke because the games and the man himself is 80% gimmick and 20% one liners. This was no exception. So I can't just say it was too gimmicky. Because no ♥♥♥♥ Sherlock,  it's Duke Nukem. Problem is, there was 98% gimmick, 10% one liners and 0.5% things to kill. That was the big negative to me. There was too much focusing on memes that were sometimes not even duke related. There was too much gimmick happening and not enough shooting stuff. Like the minigames that are almost memes themselves at this point. It was like the game was trying to make up for lost time in the self-referential humor and thus you got huge spans of non-action sequences like the strip club. Make no mistake, Duke has always been about being cheesy and awesome and killing swathes of enemies. But this didn't have much of that all things considered.

Now let me get something straight, I'm a straight man and like any straight man I like women and I like boobs. I've seen and touched many of both in my time. So believe me when I say that there were way, way too many instances of omg look boobs!" Just way too many
date: it's what you'd expect either a kid or a sexually frustrated adult to put into a video game. Like I said before lots of boob is perfect for Duke because he's Duke. Which is why the strip clubs in the original games were just fine. It was over the top and just great. But this is over the top to the point where someone fell down and broke their neck.\n\nOther thing that almost made me create a review just to rant was the ♥♥♥♥ing hoover dam underwater ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Holy crap. This level frustrated me almost to the point of just stopping right then and there. I don't like underwater levels in 3D games in the first place but I do acknowledge they can be done right. This wasn't. It brought the pace of the game to a screeching halt even worse than the non-action sequences. I died more times in the leech fight and the area near it than anywhere else in the game including the final boss (which I actually died 0 times on so that should say something). Simply because I couldn't move fast. I know you're  thinking "you just have no skill". Maybe that's true
recommended: but this was not a matter of skill. Skill cannot be used when you move like a bug through taffy. It gives you little opportunities to artfully dodge like you could in just about every other game.\n\nThat said
hoursPlayed: the final fight made up for it and it was suitably epic. Still
voteText: not sure I can recommend it. Even though I think the absolute nail biting hate towards it is kind of silly I do understand to an extent. It's not faithful to the material. Even though I love hearing Jon and all that. It just lacked the gameplay. Which was a gigantic part of Duke 3D and such. If you liked those there is no real guarantee you'll like this one. There's just not enough gameplay and too much pandering and meme-whoring and not enough of what made the series great in the first place: Killing things. Killing lots of things and killing lots of things in a smooth and flowing manner."

reviewText:
Where oh where do I start with this one ><


This isnt a game for the average gamer. Some may take offence. Some may hate the game itself, Some just may hate the fact that the wait for this game was over ten years (YES WE ALL WERE EXCITED FOR THAT GAME GET OVER IT!!), and after everything devs etc went thru still put out an amazing game.

Yes you see it for $5 at local game shops and usually on steam key sites for $10.

but if you enjoy Hilarious comments, blood and guts, babes, bewbs. This is for you!

The Campaign is pretty damn good, a good challenge on the hardest difficulty, loads of random stuff throughout the game
and a good game on normal as well. No Learning curve easy to play if you play COD etc.


the Multiplayer is fun but if you live in Aus then you going to have no luck finding a Aus server. soo 300ping minimum is the norm. But no bots for MP is a bummer as well as taking forever to level up your Duke.

The DLC for this game The Docter who cloned me is a single player campaign which happens after the final boss events. (wont say more) but im enjoying so far you fight urself >.<

The Multiplayer DLC, Hail to The parody Icons Packs introduces new guns, maps and game modes with references to game(not sure which)

But if you see the complete package on sale I recommend picking it up ^^

reviewText:
3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games really knocked it out of the park with this game. After 15 years of development hell the first true masterpiece in video games is here.
The game takes a lot of cues from modernist fiction. Much of the game is about topics such as sadness, loss, addiction, alcoholism, failure, family, mental health, morality, PTSD, fame, chaos, masculinity, spirituality and isolation. The structure of Duke Nukem Forever reinforces this and the entire game is split up into vignettes all structured like a recursive fractalic ionizing radiation symbol.
The game is set years after the first alien invasion and chronicles the post-war life of duke much in the same way the Greek dark age poem The Odyssey talks about Odysseus' struggle with post-war life and the hard transition for him. The game picks up shortly after the alien war. Duke has fallen on hard times, after an unsuccessful spout in politics, his failing business ventures leave him facing bankruptcy. The game switches then to 7 years later, duke is no longer remembered as the savior of earth and is forced into private life as a used car salesman married to a woman who doesn't love him and who is cheating on him. Duke falls into a deep depression and visions of his past haunt him at night, slowly the visions creep into the day and this vignette ends with a violent outburst in which duke believes the aliens have come back to earth.
Now it's 3 years later, duke is an a mental facility dealing with the horrors of his past. His wife has left him and he struggles with a lot of health problems in this chapter. One of the patients in the facility recognizes duke but slowly over the course of the vignette the player realizes that the patient thinks that Duke is the great king Gilgamesh a champion of masculinity from the ancient near eastern epic poem.
Duke next transition is into the desert, set only a year later duke is living on the outskirts of Las Vegas. Duke is forced into an emasculating job as a male ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who is forced to do disgusting acts for peanuts. Duke is slowly drinking himself to death in an attempt to kill the pain in his life. At several times during the course of this phase in his life he wanders drunk through the desert, in the last of this section Duke is lost in the desert for 40 days before reaching civilization and being tested with addiction by a strip club and gives into his desire. This section mirrors the temptation of Christ but twists the ending.
The next section takes place only 3 days later, Duke is an emasculated, mess of a man make impotent by the drink. Duke jumps off the Hoover Dam but fails and lands onto a child.
Duke wakes up in a prison hospital missing his left leg. Duke has been sentenced to life without parole for drug possession and killing the child at the end of the of previous chapter. In the hospital the doctors discover Duke has prostate cancer from the steroids duke took during his youth. Duke loses all masculinity after his surgery and develops into a fat, sexless man confined to a wheelchair. Duke yet again falls into a deep pit of depression and wants to kill himself but just can't do it. It's implied that Duke is bottom to his cell partner. Duke dreams of the aliens from Duke Nukem 3D returning and him regaining his former glory and fame. Duke wakes up and starts crying, he reflects on his life and all the paths that brought him to his current state. Duke hangs himself in his prison cell.
This game is a truly bold move for the franchise and has entered gaming into a brave new world of creativity and story telling.

reviewText:
An enjoyable mistake. This game really isn't as bad as people say it is. With great realistic creature design and good competent graphics. Amusing jokes and one-liners, keeping Duke's ego strong. And some pretty awesome weapons to blow the ♥♥♥♥ out of those alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with.

If you were to compare this game to Duke Nukem 3D, the game flops when it comes to level design a severe downgrade from the open level, secret filled levels of 'Duke Nukem 3D', changing it to a very linear scripted shooter. And there is a 2 weapon limit in place, meaning that you are unable to carry Duke's entire arsenal. Also regenerating health has been added making the gameplay ALOT less thrilling and ALOT more boring.

If you just want a game where you can be a total bad-♥♥♥ blowing the ♥♥♥♥ out of aliens, this is the game to play but be aware of its dated game design and problems

reviewText:
I played Duke Nukem 3D years ago and it was a really great shooter.

This sequel features decent-to-good level design, and a nice set of enemies to fight.

The gameplay is more modern since you cannot carry all weapons and your health refills along time.

One disappointing thing comes with the relative low efficiency of some weapons you imagined more potent (relative to the ego of the character), namely the revolver and the shotgun. So you end up gunning down aliens mostly with the triple cannon machinegun.

The story is purely decorative and the characters flat as a carpet. Half of the time the soldiers are coward and stupid, but that does not make Duke intelligent or brave.

It could have been a decent shooter but the game is blatantly sexist. Of course it comes with the character, but as far as I remember, all the female characters are either : horny at the mere sight of the Duke, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ providers, incapable of saving themselves, sex workers, alien surrogate mothers begging you to shoot them. I don't recall any female soldiers, scientists or civilians worth noticing. The developers pushed the envelope up to the following point : aliens are only abducting women, so you have to save them!

Is there an irony here? Maybe aliens are in fact abducting women to protect from the Duke? That would have been a hell of a twist!

So if you're confortable with that level of sexism, Duke Nukem Forever deserved a 6/7 as a shooter. Otherwise it's preferable to ignore it.

reviewText: To be fair, there is some merit to this game. The environments and enemies look well enough, certainly not cutting edge but well past the limits of the sixth generation. There's even a small bit of platforming and puzzle solving, such as the remote control cars, running around in miniature, and bouncing inside an alien mother ship. There's lots of items strewn about with which the player can interact, like a fully functioning pinball machine, and boss fights usually depend on some gimmick instead of firepower.\nUnfortunately, none of these distractions are fully realized or satisfying, and only serve to interrupt very claustrophobic gun-play through narrow hallways and trenches. There a plenty of scripted set-pieces that reinforce this sense of linearity, creating spectacle at the expense of freedom, like being lifted by a crane or manning a turret against enemy spacecraft. I enjoy linear games, but the level design here did little to excite me.\nThe other big strike against this game is its personality. For instance, in Duke Nukem 3D, the titular protagonist was fairly quiet except for the occasional musing. Forever is packed with quips, but without any restraint or comedic timing. Lines like I've got balls of fail" or "Strange silicon-based life form" wear out their welcome immediately
date: and the title is full of such groaners.\nOther stabs at humor and shock value are more questionable. When playing through an organic alien lair
recommended: the walls are decorated with disembodied breasts. Here
hoursPlayed: the player finds abductees who have been implicitly ♥♥♥♥♥ and thus impregnated with enemy fetuses. The player may either euthanize these women or allow said monsters to incubate. While I can appreciate the "No-win" scenario

reviewText: Gameplay over graphics, no matter what anyone says. You'll get a thumbs down from me otherwise.\n\nI played DN1, 2, and 3D. I played a few of the old console ones too. reviewText: Although the reviews have been harsh, Duke Nukem Forever didn't fail my expectations as a classic linear first-person shooter. Voiced by Jon St. John, Duke returns with nothing less than his corky one liners and insatiable taste for large breasted women. This game leaves me wanting to play the original Duke Nukem 3D so, to me, it does fullfill a fan boy's dream of returning as one of PC gaming's most memorable characters. reviewText: I went into this game with extremely low expectations and was pleasantly surprised. This is a good game. It is not mindblowing, it is just another run-of-the-mill shooter, about as sophisticated as Call of Duty. There is hardly any story. It's all immature fart jokes and ♥♥♥♥. You can pick up ♥♥♥♥ and throw it. This is what you should expect from a Duke Nukem game.\n\nThe controls are tight, the level design is interesting but borders on tedious. The action is fast-paced but lacking. It won't take you long to finish. It's definitely not a memorable experience but it's not as bad as the gaming hivemind makes it out to be, it even got a couple laughs from me. If you want to truly enjoy this game, turn off your brain and pretend you're 12 years old again.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I gave it every chance in the world, and ignored every bit of criticism the game got. First, I'd like to say that at no point was it ever going to live up to the hype that was around the game. It could have came out and been the GOTY and still wouldn't have lived up to the buildup.

What the game does right is make long time fans of the franchise nostaligic for the classic games. All of the things that made you love Duke as a character are back. Sadly, the game is tedious to play. It's not fun or that challenging, but it's infuriating for all the wrong reasons. I don't care when games ♥♥♥♥ me off because they're hard. This one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off because of the poor controls and glitches.

I can't recommend buying this game at full price. I would only buy it during a sale at a steep discount, and you'll probably regret not buying one of the other better Duke Nukem games. But if they announced a new Duke Nukem even after this game I'd buy it. Always bet on Douk.

reviewText:
Ahhh, Duke Nukem Forever. The mythical game that was never to be released.

Sadly, it shouldn't of been. Duke Nukem had his time in the 90's; when his particular brand of macho humor was well appreicated and seen for the comedy it was. These days, however, Duke's practically trademark sense of humor is as outdated as it is offensive.

The game itself plays host to a variety of other mechanics seemingly lifted from other games; mechanics that have since been refined in others, but kept in a very raw form in this game. The overall impression being that the developers ran through a list of potentional game mechanics in a pick'n'mix fashion. That said, the developers have done a wonderful job of keeping the game stable, with no crashes or other problems noted.

But, if you can look past the seemingly poor gameplay mechanics, and the humor that is so awful it's actually insulting everyone rather than trying to make them laugh...you wind up with a liner first person shooter filled with the reanimated enemies of games long since past and very large amounts of womenfolk who really, REALLY need to put on some damn clothes. It feels like I've been sucked into a 14 year old's wet dream, to be frank.

This, it seems, is Duke's swan song. He needs to go back into retirement alongside his troupe of scantiliy clad women (that may or may not be aliens) as the gaming community wishes him well.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever suffers from one, fatal flaw: It didn't come out ten years ago and is roughly the same game you see now. The final build for the single player was apparently finished about two or three years ago by Triptych and 3D Realms. For whatever reason in licensing land the game has only surfaced now to be greeted with bad criticism, which is very understandable.

The single player is rather fun though, even if it does show how dated it already is. If you are to pick this game up, you really need to pretend that it came out back in 2009, or maybe even earlier if you want to give the game considerable leeway.

Try this game when it becomes a bargain bin title, as some concepts like the shrunken Duke sections are really neato, but in reality, the game becomes rather defunct once you've beaten the game.

Don't even bother with the multiplayer as dedicated servers haven't even been working since launch, which shows enough how much they cared about it.

reviewText: The game had Duke humor to the core. It was a joy to see this back in action. Duke still had flare and style that only Duke can have. The Singleplayer  Campaign didn't take very long and was a joy to beat. To be warned there is nudity in this game and adult humor so if your sensitive to that kind of stuff then stay away from this game. The Multiplayer aspect of this game is still active and alot of fun to play with. There are separate in-game achievements for the Multiplayer side of the game. The graphics look not as crisp as today's game but it still does the job. The game is a must have for any Duke Nukem fan, it brings the old enemies into this game and puts more character into them. This was awesome to play and I really enjoyed it. Make sure to find this one on sale to earn Your Balls of Steel"."

reviewText:
My past history with Duke Nukem: I played the first Shareware Duke Nukem hundreds of times, as it was one of the few games I had on my IBM PS/2 (with a model M keyboard, I might add!). I did not play much of the Duke Nukem later series, nor did I play the Duke 3D very much.

I know that Duke Nukem Forever was one of the most hyped games of all times (tying with Half Life 3 and Starcraft 2). Perhaps it was the expectations that drove the reviews to be so critical. It's not a great game. It has some corny dialog. But as I played it, I enjoyed it. Perhaps bolstered by the low price tag and a little Jameson's, I've thought it was a great deal.

DNF is fun, as a standalone game. If you can pick it up on one of the frequent sales, it's worth playing.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever is a game you will either love or hate, depending on what expectations you had towards this sequel.

Haters will probably argue it's not a worthy successor to the series, it's unfinished, it's buggy, it's boring - and that might be true if you're desperately looking for reasons to hate the game.

Personally, I found DNF to be one of the most hilarious and funny games I've played in a while. This game does so many things right and has so much to offer to keep you entertained throughout the whole game, which will approx. last ~15 hours (including the DLC).

Boobs? Check.
Legendary Duke Nukem one-liners? Check.
Hilarious dialogues? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Interactive games inside the game? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Funny easter eggs? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Drivable forklifts? Check.
Boobs? Check.

DNF brings all the fun back into video games without taking itself or the video game industry too serious and that's something rare these days. If you're looking for some fun, buy DNF!
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever suffers from one, fatal flaw: It didn't come out ten years ago and is roughly the same game you see now. The final build for the single player was apparently finished about two or three years ago by Triptych and 3D Realms. For whatever reason in licensing land the game has only surfaced now to be greeted with bad criticism, which is very understandable.

The single player is rather fun though, even if it does show how dated it already is. If you are to pick this game up, you really need to pretend that it came out back in 2009, or maybe even earlier if you want to give the game considerable leeway.

Try this game when it becomes a bargain bin title, as some concepts like the shrunken Duke sections are really neato, but in reality, the game becomes rather defunct once you've beaten the game.

Don't even bother with the multiplayer as dedicated servers haven't even been working since launch, which shows enough how much they cared about it.

reviewText:
A very solid and enjoyable FPS game worth the price, or on sale if you're not sure.  Be the Duke in an action adventure FPS spanning Las Vegas to the Hoover Dam and more, if you have The Docter Who Cloned Me DLC that is, which feels more like the real ending to the game and is just as entertaining as the main game. Shoot pigcops, shout one-liners, bench press 600 pounds, throw stool, raise your ego meter, drink beer, take steriods, and more in one of the best FPS games ever made. If you enjoy FPS games, Half-Life, action movies, and Toy Story this game may be for you.


Whatever you do don't play if you're offended by everything otherwise you'll hate this game just as much as the militant anti-social justice warriors writing for sleazy hack media sites did when they slandered this game and the developers upon release due to it's usage of mild nudity, language, blood and gore, drugs and alcohol, and suggestive themes. reviewText:
7/10

Lets start from Cons to Pros

*He may be the WORST version of Duke Nukem. Duke was meant to be every manly stereotype tossed into 1 man (minus a beard apparently.) He is suppose to be the badass every man wants to be. Yet this ♥♥♥♥♥ version needs to regenerate health, can't handle even 1 beer, and can only hold his breath for 10 seconds.

*Lets start with regen health. It is ok, but I would feel better if I had my healthkit item to carry to repair my health at last minute, not hide around a corner and wait for my health to go back up. Kills most challenge for me.

*The 1 beer thing is bull, come on.. even I can handle ONE beer.. I don't even drink. I get it is a power thing, but come on.. 1 beer, completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.. Insane.

*He can only hold his breath for 10 seconds (I just tried, I was fine for 40 seconds. Come on Duke, Nut up.).. which makes 1 bossfight annoying because you have to stop to fill up oxygen every few seconds, making that fight annoying.. Not even harder, just, annoyingly longer than it needs to be.

*The other thing was the 2 gun limit. They DID fix it thank god with a option to let you equip up to 4 guns at once, but still, why should it be needed? Duke is the kind of man to kill everything, anyway he wants. Why even consider limiting your choices?

*The bosses are only hurt by RPG and turrents?? Really? That alone I feel breaks what duke stood for. If I wanna punch a boss to death, let me. Don't limit my choices down, and take any creativity on how I beat the game away.

*Finally, the nightvision.. oh my god.. can it be anymore blinding? Thank god you only need to use it like 2 - 3 times.. but damn, just bright blue and white everywhere. Terrible.. I would of rather a flashlight or even a darker green nightvision.

_____________________________________________________________
My personal hatred is the graphics issues. May just be my computer, would like to know if this is a common issues.

The ripper, rpg, freezeray cause my screen to flicker when walking with it out. favorite weapons, and they bother my eyes a bit.

But the good things, the reason I will gladly replay it.

*The story wasn't terrible. I personally liked the DN1 and 2 with a more serious story of a badass facing a robot army over a guy who has to hit on every girl he sees. But just my opinion.

*I hear the weapons are unbalanced but I saw no issue using any of them, even the pistol was useful.

*The boss fights were interesting and well done, all took different ways of winning.

*The exacution option is awesome and fun.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever is a game you will either love or hate, depending on what expectations you had towards this sequel.

Haters will probably argue it's not a worthy successor to the series, it's unfinished, it's buggy, it's boring - and that might be true if you're desperately looking for reasons to hate the game.

Personally, I found DNF to be one of the most hilarious and funny games I've played in a while. This game does so many things right and has so much to offer to keep you entertained throughout the whole game, which will approx. last ~15 hours (including the DLC).

Boobs? Check.
Legendary Duke Nukem one-liners? Check.
Hilarious dialogues? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Interactive games inside the game? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Funny easter eggs? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Drivable forklifts? Check.
Boobs? Check.

DNF brings all the fun back into video games without taking itself or the video game industry too serious and that's something rare these days. If you're looking for some fun, buy DNF!

reviewText:
This game is really not as bad as people would have you believe. I played through it multiple times, and although it sometimes feels a little dated, the humour is spot-on. I anjoyed many of the mechanics and I definately enjoy many of the levels. The graphics are overall not something to write home about, but sometimes I did find myself pleasantly surprised by a certain scene or effect.

For those of you who played it and didnt think it lives up to the hype, remember, this game was more than a decade in the making, went through a lot of developer issues and outgrew 3 different game engines. Were lucky to have this at all. Also, I invite you to replay the original, it might give you an appreciation for how much they improved some aspects.

Buy it and support Duke, he's gonna need it if we want another one! I personally don't think you will be dissapointed!

reviewText:
15 years. We waited 15 years for this mindless slog. Maybe it's my age maturing (NAHH!!!), maybe it's that the game tries to be DUke Nukem 3d with modern graphics? Maybe cause it was terribly written, terribly directed and terribly made game that would have been more entertaining if never released so we can continue to speculate and make our own stories up,

this is just a bad game. Be prepared for limiting weapon choices that don't make much sense, don't actually work well and are so boring. Be prepared for running down straight corridors with no choices of any direction in a world that seems to be overly infatuated with Duke and his sexual exploits.

its very rare that a game was better off as vapour ware. But this is one of them.

If you're a Duke Nukem die hard, Find it on sale so that you can experience it. But the experience will leave you scratching your head wondering is this really how I remember him?". The one liners here are forced and overused. the sexual innuendo isn't remotely subtle like the first game

reviewText:
DNF has been forever in the making & has finally arrived. DNF might lack story & character depth [that's for sure] & the graphics might look 5 years OLD, but DNF surely can be a lot of fun b/c when DNF is on, DNF is on point. When it's not, well...it's not.

DNF is a shooter, but it often tries to be more than a shooter - also having a puzzle-physics elements & tons of interactivity w/ objects in the game-world.

The on & off early part of the SP portion might throw the player for a loop, but don't quit yet - the game gets better once you leave The Lady Killer casino...A LOT better. Later on, a few levels are pointless [the strip club] or often repetitive [the get gas 3 times for the truck mission] - which unfortunately also drag the game's quality down a quite a bit.

The MP feels like a throwback to the good old days of DN3D; Quake 2 + 3 glory; and UT days, which is welcome - but, if only there were more maps & game modes.

DNF certainly might not be worth the original $60 price-tag, but DNF surely is worth the $20 or less that it is often going for now.

Grade: C+

reviewText:
Its Duke...nuff said. Buy if you want to have fun blasting things and belting one liners. Don't buy if you demand over the top emotionless heroes and a save the world at all cost storyline. Even 12 years later, Duke is still the king of FPS fun.

Graphically some levels look dated. But getting past those, other parts look quite nice.

This is the series which inspired countless others since DN3D. Its a good return to the roots. Fans of the original, this is a must buy.

reviewText:
Quite an enjoyable game. The jokes are token Duke, the references to other movies/games are fun to stumble across, and the game is well designed.
Limited ammo resources means that you either have to be conservative with ammunition or ready to switch weapons at any time; so having a 'favourite weapon' means you run the risk of running out of ammo mid-fight.
Gameplay is kept fresh by often switching between FPS, rail shooter, platformer, driving challenge, quicktime events, and puzzle solving (on a very basic level) so that the game keeps from ever getting repetetive.

I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this game. The price tag might be high, but it's a game worth supporting.

reviewText:
After all the bashing reviews, I feel obliged to recommend you DNF. I didn't give a fu*k about reviews and I had an oldschool blast.

Yes, the game is vulgar, highly NSFW and full of primitive one-liners. Not as great as old action movies but sometimes close.

I loved the old feeling - the old level design, weapons, and being stuck for some time which resulted in asking Internet for help on 2-3 occasions - which I really loved, reminded me of good old times. Also, game is quite hard, not like today's games are. Plus, million ingame minigames (pinball etc.).

Oh, and how much you will love boss fights! They're just awesome.

Pros - level design, boss fights, Duke, difficulty, minigames.
Cons - autoheal (but it's a little bit spiced up), some levels & something I can't remember.

It's not the best game out there and I'd be probably a little bit disappointed if I bought it on release date, but nowadays it's great FPS for a budget price, especially if you miss the gaming from 10 years ago.

reviewText: This is not really as bad as a lot of people claim it is.  I do feel that it spends way too much time screwing around instead of letting you actually go out and shoot things.  There are entire chapters of the game that have no shooting and instead just have you wandering around looking for stuff or exploring an environment, and those can get boring very fast.  But when the game remembers that it's supposed to be a first person shooter and lets you shoot some aliens, it's still pretty fun for the most part.  I found the difficulty curve to be a bit off with the bosses;  one boss at around the 3/4ths mark was insanely hard, but then the next boss and the final boss were easy.  Overall, there is some fun to be had here, so if you see it on sale, grab it.  I got it for $10 and wasn't disappointed at that price.\n\nThis game does earn its M rating though, so be warned if any of the content mentioned in the ESRB decription would offend you.

reviewText: Leagues behind its predecessor in terms of level design and overall cohesion of gameplay but still a decent game and nowhere near the abomination that most of the press claims it to be. 8 guns in total (you can carry up to 4), gun management is bad (cycle only no keybinds for guns), levels are varied and there is a bit of platforming/puzzle gameplay in the mix. Campaign took me 11 hrs on hard to finish. The game takes a while to set the pace as the 1st couple of levels have you interacting with the environments/ playing mini-games but it gets progressively better. Difficulty feels uneven at times as there are some difficulty spikes here and there that slow down the pace at which you progress. The game throws a lot of references/ jokes at you with mixed results. Just don't expect highbrow humour from Duke.  All in all if you want to leave your brain at the door and play a fun game that has you chuckling along the way then this title is a prime candidate.

reviewText:
After all the bashing reviews, I feel obliged to recommend you DNF. I didn't give a fu*k about reviews and I had an oldschool blast.

Yes, the game is vulgar, highly NSFW and full of primitive one-liners. Not as great as old action movies but sometimes close.

I loved the old feeling - the old level design, weapons, and being stuck for some time which resulted in asking Internet for help on 2-3 occasions - which I really loved, reminded me of good old times. Also, game is quite hard, not like today's games are. Plus, million ingame minigames (pinball etc.).

Oh, and how much you will love boss fights! They're just awesome.

Pros - level design, boss fights, Duke, difficulty, minigames.
Cons - autoheal (but it's a little bit spiced up), some levels & something I can't remember.

It's not the best game out there and I'd be probably a little bit disappointed if I bought it on release date, but nowadays it's great FPS for a budget price, especially if you miss the gaming from 10 years ago.

reviewText:
DNF has been forever in the making & has finally arrived. DNF might lack story & character depth [that's for sure] & the graphics might look 5 years OLD, but DNF surely can be a lot of fun b/c when DNF is on, DNF is on point. When it's not, well...it's not.

DNF is a shooter, but it often tries to be more than a shooter - also having a puzzle-physics elements & tons of interactivity w/ objects in the game-world.

The on & off early part of the SP portion might throw the player for a loop, but don't quit yet - the game gets better once you leave The Lady Killer casino...A LOT better. Later on, a few levels are pointless [the strip club] or often repetitive [the get gas 3 times for the truck mission] - which unfortunately also drag the game's quality down a quite a bit.

The MP feels like a throwback to the good old days of DN3D; Quake 2 + 3 glory; and UT days, which is welcome - but, if only there were more maps & game modes.

DNF certainly might not be worth the original $60 price-tag, but DNF surely is worth the $20 or less that it is often going for now.

Grade: C+

Writing this out of boredom. You should know by now how much of a disappointment the base game is.

Stupid linearity, broken online, regenerating health, lack of intelligent enemies, stupid time wasting puzzles, 2 weapon limit upon launch, big patches of scenery that look worse than the 2000 trailer.

This seems like a huge mistake to buy, because its as dated as you would expect for a vaporware project that was picked up, and turned into a polished turd: no matter how you look at it- your holding a piece of ♥♥♥♥.

However what surprised me about this game was the Doctor who cloned me DLC. that extra campaign made the game into a polished turd with a gem inside. Still cant recommend it unless you have nothing else to play

reviewText: No, I will not recommend this piece of garbage. reviewText: There are a lot of gameplay elements that I love in this game, and I hate that they're in something so profoundly marred.   Women only appear in this game as sexual objects.  That's been a core part of Duke Nukem since at least 3D, but that doesn't make it OK.  And it ends up going past sexism and into misogyny.  Then you reach the Hive level and mix in body horror; it's disgusting in ways I don't think the developer intended.\n\nThat's too bad, because I really enjoyed the actual gameplay.  The basic shooting mechanic was a lot of fun.  I never got bored during the enemy encounters.  Some were really frustrating, but I was always able to get through by changing tactics.  It's full of great interactive bits like working air hockey and pinball games.  I was laughing so hard when I started drawing on a whiteboard and an NPC commented on it.  The later half of the game that was all about fighting aliens and making references to games and movies I like was great.  I wish they'd just done that.  Then I could give it a whole-hearted thumbs-up.

reviewText:
I really tried, but this game was unbelievably generic and stupid.  It was almost written and programmed with the target demographic of teenage boys and people who haven't played a decent shooter since the early 90's.

And perhaps that's just it - they attempted (and failed) to make a piece of video game nostalgia that gives a middle finger to the games that preceded it, as if it's doing something better by being simpler (and dumber).

Here's a Halo joke, here's some big-breasted women in private school uniforms, and here's a bunch of random set-pieces with moving targets to shoot.

The whole Duke Nukem Forever design timeline is a real shame.  I heard the developers kept scrapping each current project when a new game engine was released, rebuild for the new one only to do the same once a NEWER engine was announced.  This is really telling and goes back to my early point that these developers started working on this project during a simpler time in shooter game design".  There was still an audience for ultra-violent
date: silly shooters that were devoid of puzzles
recommended: platforming or paid DLC.\n\nBasically an "early 90's shooter ethos" mixed with an "updated" engine minus time/patience to polish off the jaggedly
hoursPlayed: crap-covered edges equals Duke Nukem Forever.\n\nRest in piece
voteText: Duke.  The king shall be hailed no more."
